physical_description: Extent: 1 choir book (52 leaves) : parchment ; 757 x 511 (590 x 345) mm, in binding 819 x 345 mm
note: Manuscript music.|Title supplied by cataloger.|Collation: Parchment, fol. 52; register of quires undetermined; tears in parchment repaired by sewing.|Layout: Written in long lines; ruled in lead-point; directions to rubricator visible.|Script: Written in textura.|Decoration: Red initials with blue pen flourishing (some with yellow highlighting); blue initials with red pen flourishing (some with green highlighting); black caligraphic initials with yellow color wash; yellow color washed litterae notabiliores.|Music: Red 5-line staves with black square notation; six staves per page. Later revisions have been made to graduals and Alleluia versicles; revisions include scraping of music and text (some scraping and renotating appears to be contemporary) and adding paper pastedowns (blank or with blank staves) over sections of music (in many instances paper pastedowns have been removed) to truncate melismas. Fol. 3v text scraped with added text in later hand A "Qua[m] dilecta tabernacula tua Domine virtutum concupiscit et deficit anima mea in atria Domini;" fol. 6r-6v added text in later hand B "Visiom[n]em quam vidistis nòmini diseritis, donec à mortuis resurgur filius omnis;" fol. 13r alternate text added in later hand B to the introit "Gaudeamus omnes" the additions "Beate Anne" and "solemnitate" to replace "Marie virginis" and "assumptione" respectively.|Origin: Written in Spain, 16th century. Probably Franciscan due to the inclusion of the feasts of St. Francis, the Stigmata of St. Francis, and St. Clare.|Manuscript annotations in Spainish on fol. 3r and 32v.

physical_description: Extent: 176] leaves : parchment ; 28 cm.
note: Incipit: "Incipit sextus liber in anno domini MCCLXXXVII Bonifacius ep[is]c[opus] s[er]vus s[er]voru[m] dei dilectis filiis doctorib[us] [et] scolaribus ... salute[m] [et] ap[osto]licam b[e]n[e]dictionem."|Explicit [as bound]: "In deg[re]dati[on]e cl[er]ico[rum] i[n] sacris ordinib[us] co[n]stituto[rum] c[er]to ep[iscop]o[rum] numero diffi[ni]to." This explicit is actually a line from Bk. 5, Title 9, Chpt. 2, and this section was placed at the end of the volume, rather than in its proper place because of a binding error. Although Boniface's text extends through Bk. 5, Title 11, Chpt. 24, the ms. was copied only as far as book 5, title 11, chapt. 22. With the ms. bound in its proper order, the explicit would read: "... satisf[a]ct[i]o[nem] exhibeant co[m]petentem si hoc cum p[ri]mum comode pot[er]u[n]t non c[ur]a u[eri]nt adi[m]plere" (cf. verso of leaf 142).|Collation: 1-178 186 19-228 232 ; quires unsigned, horizontal and vertical catchwords.|In Gothic book script (gothica textualis libraria); in two cols., 22-31 lines per p.; rubricated in alternating red and blue capitals; large initial capital in blue with red filigree decoration and red and blue pen flourishes; frame-ruled in lead in inner and outer columns, and in hard point on some leaves.|Fragment of ms. music in left margin of leaf 96v.|Includes later annotations, corrections, interlineal glosses, and marks of incomprehension.|Binding error: gatherings 178 and 186 should follow gathering 232, thus making the last sentence of leaf 186 the explicit.

Ayer."|Bookplate in red and black; woodcut vignette; illustrated woodcut compartmentalized borders in the Holbein style, containing corner monograms of Cl[audius] Pt[olemy]y and three previous owners of ms., and binder's name, "W. Pratt"; added ms. title: "Bernardus Albingavensis. Explanatio super cosmographer Ptolemei 1497-1502."|From the Visconti-Pallavicini collection; cf. leaf [4] at end; also De Ricci.|Acquired by Edward E. Ayer on May 15, 1911, possibly from Leo Olschki or Anton Hiersemann; cf De Ricci.|Forms part of the Edward E. Ayer Manuscript Collection (Newberry Library)

title_as_recorded: Unidentified manuscript fragment from northern Europe
subject_as_recorded: Manuscripts, Latin (Medieval and modern)
physical_description: Extent: 2] leaves ; 19 cm

subject_as_recorded: Bible--Concordances, Latin--Early works to 1800
physical_description: Extent: 229] leaves, bound : parchment ; 32 cm.
note: Title from ms. spine title: "Concorda[n]. Bibli[a]e"; range of dates from Rouse & Rouse.|Ms. copy of the third of three surviving medieval concordances of the Scriptures, on which the modern Latin Biblical concordance is based.|Attributed to Konrad of Halberstadt the elder, although the concordance was described in a Paris stationer's list as early as 1286, too early a date for Halberstadt to have been responsible for it. Cf. R.H. Rouse and M.A. Rouse. "The verbal concordance to the Scriptures," Archivum Fratrum Praedicatorum 44 (1979):5-30.|Gothic bookhand in brown ink, in three columns of 51 lines; light plummet ruling; catchwords in brown, within rectangular cartouche; small initials in red; capitals in first lines of columns extending into the upper margins, some with calligraphic embellishments and grotesques, in brown and red ink; 11 six- or seven-line capitals in red and blue, adorned with red and blue penwork, marking the beginning of each section (A to M); two large six- and eight-line initials in red and blue, with blue, red, and gold penwork, blue and red infill (letter C), and gold infill (letter A).|Signatures: 110(-1) 2-2310.|Originally comprising two volumes, with alphabet divided between letters A-M, and N-Z; Newberry Library has only v. 1.|A few scattered medieval marginal annotations.|Partially legible ownership inscription in bottom margin of leaf [1] indicates a Carthusian origin.|Ownership stamps throughout text of the Couvent des Pères Franciscains of Monte-Carlo, 11 Avenue Roqueville.

title_as_recorded: C]esar in Commentariis Galliam tripartiens; loca Gallie provincie a Romanis tunc possesse Britanie maioris quam agliam dicimus : Hispanie etiam citerioris ac populorum cis Rhodanum ac Rhenum flumina sitorum annectit : qui omnes linguis institutis legib[us] inter se et tu[n]c differebat
subject_as_recorded: Caesar, Julius. De bello Gallico|Isidore, of Seville, Saint, -636. Historia de regibus Gothorum, Vandalorum, et Suevorum|Gaul--History--Gallic Wars, 58-51 B.C.--Indexes
physical_description: Extent: 69] leaves, bound (last [2] leaves blank) ; 30 cm. (fol.)
note: Title from first line of text; alternative title at head of text, added later in a different hand.|Added 16th-century marginal inscriptions on recto of first leaf mention printed editions by Aldus and Paul Manutius in which Marlianus' index appeared, and suggest Jovius Alexander and Jovius de Ocelo et de Truimpilinis as possible editors or scribes.|Written in an elegant italic cursive script in at least two hands; 29-34 long lines per page; some vertical catchwords; spaces left blank for initials, with guide letters; marginal notes.|Leaves [37]-[67] contain fragments entitled "Fragmenta historica de Gothis," possibly Isidore of Seville's History of the Goths; leaf [68] contains a list of popes from Peter to Innocent VIII.|Leaves [47]-[48] are blank, marking the change of scribe.|Gap in the binding at front of ms. suggests that another text (perhaps the work related to the index, Caesar's De bello gallico itself) has been removed.|Bookplate and shelfmark of the Schoyen Collection on inside back cover.|Ms. notes and mathematical calculations on front and back endpapers and covers suggest that an earlier owner was an Italian merchant, probably a grain dealer.|Inscription on front endpaper: "Dum tempus habemus operem bonum quoniam qualis vita finis ita."

title_as_recorded: Tarih-i Yeni Dünya, el-musemma be hadis-i nev
subject_as_recorded: America--Early accounts to 1600|America--Discovery and exploration--Spanish--Early works to 1800|Discoveries in geography--Early works to 1800|Manuscripts, Turkish|Illumination of books and manuscripts
physical_description: Extent: 107] leaves, bound, [6] leaves of plates : 13 color illustrations, 3 color maps ; 26 cm.
note: Text in Arabic "nesih" script, rubricated, within gold and black borders; illuminated head-piece is a gold cartouche on a lapis background decorated with gold, red, turqoise, and white flowers; on heavy yellowish glazed paper.|Thirteen color miniatures illustrate textual descriptions of native American flora and fauna, such as the coconut, guava, and banana trees, cochineal cactus, tapir, armadillo, bison, pelican, and jaguar; a landscape of the Peruvian town of Potosí, with its silver mountain; and two imaginary drawings of a merman, and a wak-wak tree, bearing fruit in the form of naked women. Cf. Goodrich.|Three double-page maps, oriented with the south at the top, illustrated in red, blue, black, white, and gold with small pictures of cities and sailing ships, and borders in gold and black. Includes two circular hemispheric maps (24 cm.) of the Old and New Worlds, and a rectangular mappa mundi (19 x 26 cm.), very similar to the one by J. Gastaldi in Geografiya di Claudio Ptolemeo (Venice, 1548).|First printed in Constantinople in 1730 by Ibrahim Müteferrika; reprinted in 1875 without the maps. Cf. Goodrich.|English translation of the Newberry ms. by Thomas D. Goodrich in Ottoman Turks and the New World: a study of Tarih-i Hind-i garbi and sixteenth-century Ottoman Americana. Wiesbaden : Harrassowitz, 1990.|Acquired by Edward E. Ayer in 1901 from Dr. Cyrus Adler.|Forms part of the Edward E. Ayer Manuscript Collection (Newberry Library)

Foyle.

note: Place of production suggested by reference on p. 114 to Saint Odilia, abbess and patroness of Alsace: "In translatione S. Odiliae Ord. Patrona."|In elegant rounded roman letters and graceful musical notation, with other music and prayers added later by at least two other, less-skilled copyists.|Music arranged on red 4-line staves, with square notation in black; four staves per page; large decorative initials, some in red, and some in red, black, and gold; prayers, responses, and instructions in red and black (mostly red).|Watermark of the letter "P" atop three circles suggests that paper was manufactured in the Netherlands, possibly Loosduinen, around 1599; cf. Briquet no. 1371.

subject_as_recorded: Rueda, Rodrigo de, active 1553-1569|Rueda, Luis de, active 1553-1569|Rueda, Bernardino de, active 1553-1569|Rueda, Baltasar de, active 1553-1569|Rueda family|Nobility--Spain--Carmona--History--16th century--Sources|Heraldry--Spain--Carmona--History--16th century--Sources|Manuscripts, Spanish--Spain--Granada|Illumination of books and manuscripts--Spain--Specimens|Bookbinding--Specimens|Carmona (Seville, Spain)--Genealogy|Carmona (Seville, Spain)--History--16th century--Sources
material_as_recorded: parchment, col. ill, coat of arms, port.
physical_description: Extent: 106] leaves, bound : parchment, col. ill, coat of arms, port. ; 33 cm (fol.)
note: Title from summary line at bottom of leaf [101].|Leaves [4]-[6] fully illustrated in gold and brilliant colors: verso of leaf [4] contains portrait of the Madonna and Child, flanked by side panels filled with small paintings of human figures, grotesque heads, leaves, and fruits on gold background; facing p. depicts King Philip in black kneeling before the crucified Christ, with similar illuminated panels on sides. Verso of leaf [5] shows the risen Christ victorious over death; and below, the king on horseback slaying his enemies on the battlefield. Facing p. contains coat of arms of the Rueda family. Portrait of the king in black and scarlet against a gold background, and within a gold frame on verso of leaf [100].|Contemporary dark leather binding over boards; roll patterns of concentric panels on upper and lower boards are blind rules, and gold-tooled garlands of leaves, and small ornaments depicting skulls and bones, lions, and soldiers' heads; spine has raised bands and gold-stamped ornaments in each panel; all edges gilt; two guard leaves of red silk between illustrated leaves; two red, green, gold, and white twisted cords bound in centerfold; lead seals once held by cords are no longer present.|First [3] and last [5] leaves are blank.|Bookplate of Henry Probasco, dated Dec. 1, 1890.|Forms part of the Henry Probasco Collection at the Newberry Library.|Text in a single elegant rotunda hand in black; red-ruled, with double borders in red and gold; added certification at end in a different hand; 34 lines per page; opening words in gold letters on red and blue painted compartments; large gold initials in alternating red and blue compartments decorated with white penwork; smaller gold initials on red and blue backgrounds throughout text; interrogatory questions numbered i-xii in margins.

title_as_recorded: Commentary on Book 4 of the Sententiae of Peter Lombard
subject_as_recorded: Peter Lombard, Bishop of Paris, approximately 1100-1160. Sententiarum libri IV.--Liber 4--Criticism and interpretation|Catholic Church--Doctrines--Early works to 1800|Theology--History--Middle Ages, 600-1500|Theology, Doctrinal--History--Middle Ages, 600-1500|Sacraments--Catholic Church--Early works to 1800|Perfection--Religious aspects--Catholic Church--Early works to 1800|Teleology--Early works to 1800|Manuscripts, Latin (Medieval and modern)
physical_description: Extent: 32] leaves ; 22 x 33 cm or smaller.
note: Title supplied by cataloger.|Possible date and place of production suggested by watermark.|Bastarda script in a single hand, with tight line-spacing; text and bounding lines in brown ink; two-line lombards at the beginning of the "quaestiones" and "articuli", paragraph marks, underlining, and roman numeral column "titles" all in red; some blank areas between columns of text in sections 49 and 50 contain designs of radiating lines and curlicues in red; ascenders of a few letters decorated with red and brown penwork resembling birds' heads, butterfly wings or spider webs.|Watermark: ox-head, with eyes only, topped with a star/asterisk. Piccard (6:273) identifies use between 1416-1423 in Heilbronn, Cadolzburg, Munich, Nuremberg, and Würzburg. Cf. also Briquet ("tete-de-boeuf") nos. 14624-14653, esp. 14643, 14645, and 14647, used between 1411-1430 in Nuremberg, Helmschofen, and Würzburg.|Some loss of text due to tears, wormholes, and dark staining.|Traces of glue and bits of printed text stuck to some of the leaves suggest ms. was used as binding reinforcement for another work.|Leaves arranged in four manila folders, within a binder having printed title: "Sammlung Freiherr von Gasser [cross] München", possibly a reference to Baron Rudolf von Gasser, Bavarian ambassador to St. Petersburg for many years, who may have owned the ms. at one time. In Feb. 1912, following Gasser's death, his collection of European ceramics was sold at auction by Galerie Hugo Helbing in Munich.|For additional information, consult the Special Collections Info File.

title_as_recorded: Heures de la crois; Domine labia mea aperies et os meum annuntiab[i]t laudem tuam
subject_as_recorded: Catholic Church--Prayers and devotions--Latin--Early works to 1800|Catholic Church--Liturgy--Texts|Books of hours|Manuscripts, Latin (Medieval and modern)
physical_description: Extent: 91] leaves, bound : parchment, color illustrations ; 21 cm
note: Title from first line of text on leaf [7].|Textura script in red and brown; text and margins lightly-ruled in brown ink; 18 lines per page; large illuminated capitals: blue and white, or brown and gold, on blue, brown, or green panels decorated with tiny flower and leaf motifs in gold or white; other capitals are blue or pink on contrasting panels, with letters illuminated in pink, blue, and gold checkerboard; paragraphs highlighted with small illuminated letters in gold on pink and blue panels decorated with white penwork; decorated pink and blue line fillers.|Five half-page colored paintings of Biblical scenes, each illustrating a different section of the prayer-book: the Crucifixion (Hours of the Cross); Pentecost (Hours of the Holy Spirit); the Annunciation (Hours of the Virgin); Last Judgment (Penitential Psalms and Litany); Raising of Lazarus (Office of the Dead); illuminated borders of leaves, flowers, fruits, birds, and grotesque human and animal figures in gold, blue, green, white, red, purple, and gray.|Front endpaper is a ms. leaf from the F-G section of a copy of the Concordantiae Sancti Jacobi, which was compiled under the direction of Hugh of St. Cher, a Biblical scholar from the Dominican monastery of St. Jacques in Paris, probably between ca. 1235 and 1249; text in a very fine Gothic script, arranged in 5 [?] columns per page (leaf is cropped), with each term underlined in red.|Back endpaper contains an 18-line religious poem in French on death, probably added at a later date by a different owner.|Third front flyleaf contains ownership note in northern French vernacular, identifying owner as Mademoiselle Jolent Denin [?] from Wingles, with date of 1597, possibly the year she was born. She died in Thun-Saint-Martin [Nord, France] on Dec. 10, 1624, following the death on June 8, 1624, of her father, Monsieur de Meuve, who is buried in the church in Thun-Saint-Martin.

note: Title from recto of leaf [1].|Text on vellum in a rounded secretarial hand in brown ink; text ruled in red, within double-ruled intersecting red borders; 34 lines per page; large illuminated architectural capital "R" at beginning of text, with small painting of Philip III of Spain in center; followed by three lines of small gold capitals on a red background separated by three bands of blue and adorned with gold penwork; text sections introduced by large gilt and red capitals on alternating square panels of red and blue adorned with gold or red penwork.|Verso of leaf [1] contains a large illuminated painting of the Virgin and Child, with a smaller painting below of Juan Ortiz Campoy, seated with his wife, Ynés, and his daughter, María; wide gold and red architectural border on three sides contains 15 gold medallions, each containing a painted scene from the life of Christ; red silk guard leaf.|Recto of leaf [2] contains a full-page painting of the arms and armor of the Campoy family in gray, blue, gold, green, burgundy, and ocher, with motto "Soy Canpoy"; wide gilt border filled with paintings of urns, cornucopias, flowers, winged mermaids, fountains, swans and acanthus leaves; cartouche at bottom center with date "Año 1620 y Setie. X" [Sept. 10, 1620?].|Verso of penultimate leaf, and recto and verso of last leaf have been ruled in red, but lack text.|White paper shelf mark label or filing label on upper right corner of upper board, stamped "3670."|Acquired from Edward E. Ayer by special arrangement with the Newberry Library Board of Trustees in December 1920.

material_as_recorded: parchment, color coat of arms, portraits
physical_description: Extent: 127] leaves, bound : parchment, color coat of arms, portraits ; 31 cm (folio)
note: Text on parchment, in a fine italic hand in brown ink; text within triple-ruled black borders; large illuminated gilt capital "D" at head of text, outlined in brown and decorated with the figure of a mermaid, a grotesque head in profile, and acanthus leaves in pink and yellow, on a landscape background; capitals on leaves [2]-[4] in gold, on red and blue panels ornamented with gold penwork; large black and white ornamental capitals throughout.|"Sentencia definitiva" introduced with an ornamental capital in red on leaf [111], followed by illuminated capitals in gold on landscape backgrounds, and horizontal panels of small red capitals entwined with leafy vines in green on leaves [111], [121], [122], and [125] at end.|Contains two full-page brilliantly-colored paintings: one of Nuestra Señora de los Remedios de Cogolludo receiving the prayers of the petitioner and his wife; and on the facing page, the illuminated Romero de Tejada arms in a white and silver cartouche surrounded with acanthus leaves and pennants; on a gold background atop an arrangement of banners, swords, lances, cannon, pomegranates, and leaves; 2 blue silk guard leaves bound in following leaves [1] and [2].|Verso of leaf [126] contains a smaller portrait of José Romero de Tejada, wearing a rolled powdered wig; in red, blue, green, gold, black, and white.|Royal stamp of King Philip V of Spain in bottom margin of recto of each leaf.|Former owner: Henry Probasco.|Forms part of the Henry Probasco Collection at the Newberry Library.

physical_description: Extent: 49] leaves, bound : parchment, color coats of arms ; 31 cm (fol.)
note: Title from summary line on bottom of recto of leaf [48].|Text on parchment, in a closely-spaced round italic hand, 36 lines per page; text, ruled in brown, within intersecting double-ruled borders in brown; large illuminated capital "D" outlined in dark brown, with a portrait of the Virgin and Child in center, in red, blue, and gold; on a red panel ornamented with gilt penwork; smaller gilt capitals on red and blue background, ornamented with white penwork.|Recto of last leaf ruled in brown ink, but lacking text; verso blank; prickings visible along outer margin of last four leaves.|Recto of leaf [1] is a full-page colored painting of the arms of Gonçalo Bello (Alonso Bello's grandfather) in red, white, green, blue, yellow, and gray on dark purple background; caption in ocher reads "Armas de Gonçalo Bello, caballero del auto de S[an]tiago q[ue] estan en la portada y retablo de la capilla de los Bellos en la Iglesia de Trejuncos."|Verso of leaf [2] contains a smaller coat of arms encircled with a leafy wreath, within wide illuminated borders painted with fruits, flowers, and leaves in red, blue, purple and green; facing page, separated by purple silk guard leaf, contains painting of a grotesque head wearing a basket of flowers, within the same illuminated borders of previous leaf; green silk guard leaf between leaves [45] and [46].|Acquired by the Newberry Library from Edward E. Ayer, by special arrangement with the Board of Trustees in Dec. 1920.

Cf. Special Collections Info File.|Text in black ink, in a small, closely-spaced late 16th-century hand, with numerous traditional abbreviations; ink drawings of star of David on leaves 14 (recto) and 22 (verso) of second sequence; abbreviation for Jesuit motto "Ad majorem Dei gloriam", A.M.D.G., at end of first and third sections (leaves 149 and 7, respectively) suggest possibility that author was a professor in a Jesuit institution.|Leaves 1-3 of first section, and 1-8 of second section wanting.|From the library of Raymond Berriot.|Forms part of the Edward E. Ayer Manuscript Collection (Newberry Library)

physical_description: Extent: 156] leaves, bound : parchment, col. ill., coats of arms ; 10 cm.
note: Text in a small neat gothic hand; calligraphic initials in gold on reddish-brown background; alternating smaller initials in red and blue; red and blue decorative line fillers.|Seven full-page illuminated borders of leafy sprays, fruit, animals, insects, grotesques, and sacred monograms in red, blue, green, ocher, brown, gray, and white on gilt backgrounds.|Illuminated miniatures, executed in the style of Jacques Besancon, a leading painter of the time in Paris, depict the Annunciation; the celebration of the Mass of the Dead by the abbot and canons of St. Victor; King David; St. George; and the symbols of the Four Evangelists, with the Christ Child in center.|Arms of Louis XI, and his wife, Charlotte of Savoy, both of whom died in 1483, on rectos of leaves [1] and [39]; arms of St. Victor on rectos of leaves [52] and [130]; and a heraldic shield with two skulls on verso of leaf [51].|Cf. Medieval and Renaissance manuscripts from the library of Sir Sydney Cockerell. British Library journal 13 (1978): 186-210; reference to this ms. on p. 202, no. 66.|Ownership inscription of Sydney C. Cockerell of Cambridge, dated July 13, 1911 on front endpaper, with his provenance note: "Obtained by exchange from Maggs Bros. ... It was lot 247 in a sale at Sotheby's July 13-14, 1909. The seller was Laurence Kirby of Enfield, whose wife's father, James Turle M.D. of North Finchley, obtained it from Samuel Dennis."

physical_description: Extent: 145] leaves: parchment ; 14 cm
note: Contains four texts: p. 3-73 Henricus de Hassia, Speculum anime; p. 75-206 Petrus de Alliaco, Super septem psalmos penitentiales; p. 209-275 (i.e. 277) Horae; p. 276-285 (i.e. 278-287) Oratio beati Ambrosii devota ante communionem dicenda.|Additions on flyleaves and on blank leaves between texts include memeoriae of SS. Sebastian, Erasmus, Christopher, Roche, Anthony abbot and confessor, Gregory, Andrew, Adrian, a table of years 1475-1500, and a mnemonic rule in Latin verse for finding Easter.|First two texts single column (15 lines); remaining two texts single column (17 lines).|Ruled in brown ink; textura script; rubricated.|Initials: numerous one-line blue and red initials from p. 209; over 110 two- or three-line initials in red and blue; 10 four-line decorated initials with flourished sprays in red, blue and green; one 7 line decorated penwork initial in red and blue.|Added pagination in pencil: 1-238, 238a-b, 239-289.|Written in 15-17 lines.|Gatherings of 8 leaves. Signature marks (later addition) appear at lower right corner of recto on some leaves. Catchwords appear, complete or trimmed, on the verso of the final leaf in some signatures.|Added marginalia lost due to trimming at the foot of some leaves.|Ownership inscriptions and marks on front pastedown. The first suggests Maastricht, Netherlands for origin of manuscript: Libellus fratis Petri Traiecten' ...

subject_as_recorded: Catholic Church--Liturgy--Texts|Canticles--Texts|Initials|Manuscripts, Latin|Prayer books|Psalters--Texts|Illumination of books and manuscripts--Spain--Specimens
physical_description: Extent: 148] leaves (18 lines), bound : parchment ; 15 cm.
note: Title from spine.|Gothic liturgical script.|Written in Spain. Location determined by peculiarities in the calendar, script, penwork and orthography; cf. dealer description in Special Collections Info. file.|Includes a calendar (ff.1-6v), Psalter divided into eight parts according to the Roman usage (ff.7-131v), twelve canticles (ff.131v-144v), litany (ff.144v-148), and a brief series of prayers (ff.148-148v).|The manuscript lacks the beginning of each of the Psalms introducing the eight divisions. When it was rebound the beginning of Psalm 46 was moved to the front in order to replace the missing Beatus vir page.|Initials: one- and two-line initials throughout alternately in red and blue with opposing red and blue penwork. Penwork from the two-line initials extends into the margins and sometimes ends in faces, cf. ff. 8v, 15, 49v, 58v, 115v, 130, 131v.|Gatherings of 10; catchwords.|Some marginal and inter-linear notes and corrections added later (15th cent.?), including the addition in the calendar on 20 May of St. Bernardino of Siena, who was canonized in 1450.|On the first of two parchment flyleaves preceding the calendar is a note: Ce pns livre es pour li[?] sage de seu philippe clausse 1469[?].

note: Manuscript codex.|Title from printed catalog.|Collation: Parchment, fol. 266 (error in foliation: fol. 175 should be 176); 14(-1) 212 36 412 5-610 712 8-2210 2312 24-2610 2710(-10); catchwords occasionally enclosed in rectangles present for the original book only beginning with quire 5.|Layout: Psalter written in 47 lines is two columns, remainder of the original book in 63 lines in two columns; Quires 2-3, prickings visible in outer margins; quires 5-22 and 24-26, prickings visible in lower margins; ruled in plummet.|Script: Witten in Italian gothic textualis media by at least two hands, beginning below the first ruled line; script characterized by a trailing terminal "s"; addtions in quire 23 in Italian gothic textualis media with one-story "a," long "s" slightly below the line; quire 27 written in a similar script characterized by regular use of long termial "s."|Origin: Written in Italy before or about 1230; inclusion of Dominic (canonized 1232) on fol. 86v is a correction; quires 2-4 written approximately 1260.|Decoration: fol. 5-22, 26: Alternating red and blue initials with an occasional black initial; capitals touched in red; fol. 2-4, 23 have red and blue flourished and alternating minor red and blue simple initials; fol. 27 has red initials only with black paragraph marks.|In Franciscan convent of Perugia in the second half of the 13th century; quire 1 added at this time with texts and notes written by Friar Bartholus Blancellus on fol. 1v-2v; additions to litany and calendar of Perugian saints.|Quires 23 and 26 added in the 14th century; fol. 257v, and erased ex libris illegible under ultraviolet light; fol. 226v, an erased number (16th century?), possibly a shelf-mark.|Number 8 from the collection of Henry Probasco.|Forms part of the Henry Probasco Collection at the Newberry Library.

physical_description: Extent: 113 leaves : parchment ; 156 x 109 (73 x 56) mm
note: Manuscript codex.|Title from printed catalog.|Collation: Parchment, fol. ii + 113 + iv; 112 2-98 104 118(6, stub only), 12-138 146 154; fol. 13-44, catchwords present.|Layout: Written in 14 long lines except for the calendar written in 17 long lines; ruled in violet ink.|Script: Written in cursica formata; calendar and fol. 53r-112v in lettre bâtarde media; change of scribe for the last quire.|Decoration: fol. 13r, 65r, 81r, blank space reserved for half-page miniatures with full rinceaux border decoration in the presence of gold, blue, and red initials 5 lines high; fol. 33v, 41r, 47r, 52v, 55v, bracket left margin; fol. 52v, bracket left margin; fol. 21r-104r, gold dentelle initials with white patterning on grounds of blue and magenta; fol. 1r-12r, 104v to end, gold initials on alternating red and blue grounds; fol. 13r-20r, alternating blue initials with red flourishes and red initials with black flourishes.|Origin: Written in France, probably in Le Mans, in approximately 1450; the last quire, the initials of the calendar, and the final initials may be later additions.

subject_as_recorded: Latin essays|Manuscripts, Latin (Medieval and modern)
physical_description: Extent: 272 leaves : parchment ; 252 x 170 (164 x 94) mm
note: Manuscript codex.|Title from printed catalog.|Collation: Parchment, fol. 272 (original arabic foliation in red); 1-348 (quires numbered with arabic numerals on lower margin of verso of last folio); catchwords present.|Layout: Written in 35 long lines; ruled in light pen.|Script: Written in humanistic textualis media; Greek added in a different and lighter ink; heading of principal divisions of the book in red in rustic capitals incorporating "Byzantine" elements, notably in the capital M.|Decoration: fol.1r and the beginning of each book except the first: gold initials decorated with white vine stem on grounds of pink, magenta, blue, green, and yellow 8 lines high; fol. 18r, blue initial on gold ground 17 lines high with a piece of green and gold ivy border, decorated with pink flowers; alternating red initials with violet flourishes and blue initials with red flourishes throughout; alternating simple red and blue initials in the initial section of capitula.|Origin: Written in northern Italy in 1445 by Milanus Burrus. "Finis. Per Milanum Burrum 1445." (fol. 244v).|Arms of the Finardi family of Bergamo, fol. 18r, painted over an effaced earlier coat of arms.|Initials "B.R.S.L.R." the "S' written over a triple cross, by an early modern hand, fol. 2r.|Before 1914, in the Biblioteca Molza (Modena).

subject_as_recorded: Catholic Church--Prayers and devotions--Early works to 1800|Catholic Church--Liturgy--Texts--Early works to 1800|Books of hours--Italy--Texts--Early works to 1800|Manuscripts, Latin (Medieval and modern)
physical_description: Extent: 102 leaves : parchment ; 104 x 75 (63 x 43) mm
note: Manuscript codex.|Title from printed catalog.|Front flyleaves (addition 16th century) Oratio ante missam (partially effaced), liturgical responses, the Gloria in excelsis deo ... and the Credo in deum, patrem omnipotentem, factorem celi et terrȩ ...|Collation: Parchment, fol. ii + 102; 112 2-68 74 8-118 1210 134; catchwords present, fol. 72v, visible behind an illuminated roundel; leaf signatures partially trimmed.|Layout: Written in 17 long lines; ruled horizontally in pen.|Script: Written in Italian gothic textualis rotunda.|1. Decoration: Five historiated magenta, green, and blue initials 5-6 lines high on gold grounds accompanied by full gold filigree borders decorated with green and blue flowers: fol. 13r (the Virgin and Child, a hare within a roundel in right margin), fol. 57v (David in penance, a heron-like water bird within a roundel in lower margin), fol. 72v (a human skull, a white rabbit with a white bird flying above it within a roundel in the lower margin), fol. 95v (the Cross with the instruments of torture on it; magenta laurel leaves form right margin), fol. 99r (a priest celebrating Mass accompanied by an inner bracket margin only).|2. Decoration: Magenta, blue, and green initials on gold grounds at the beginning of texts accompanied by outer bracket margins; gold dentelle initials with white patterning on grounds of magenta, blue, and green 3 lines high in the calendar accompanied by similar but simpler inner margins; the beginnings of major sections of texts marked by gold, magenta, blue, and green dentelle initials accompanied by piece border decoration; simple alternating blue and gold initials within the texts, alternating line fillers of the same colors within the litany.|Origin: Written in northern or central Italy, possibly in Bologna, in 1474 by the scribe P.S., signed with date on fol. 100v: Salve sancta parens ... hec tue optulimus maiestati. P.S. 1474.|Number 47 from the collection of Henry Probasco.|Forms part of the Henry Probasco Collection at the Newberry Library.

physical_description: Extent: 100 leaves : parchment ; 200 x 153 (148 x 103) mm
note: Manuscript codex.|Title from printed catalog.|Collation: Parchment (southern preparation), fol. ii + 100 +i; 1-1010; catchwords present: 1-2 horizontal within four dots; 3-5 within scrolls; 6-9 vertical within red dots.|Layout: Written in 37 lines in two columns; ruled in ink.|Script: fol. 1r-58v, written in humanistic textualis media, quires 1-2 by one hand, quires 3-6 (to fol. 58v) by another; fol. 58v-100r, written in Italian gothic textualis media, with one-story a and trailing terminal s beginning on the first ruled line throughout.|Decoration: Square roman capitals illuminated in magenta, blue, or gold, decorated with green acanthus spray, fol. 1r, 11r, and 16vv; alternating red and blue minor rustic capital initials, washed with yellow throughout.|Origin: Written in central Italy during the pontificate of Paul II (1464-1471). Note of 15th century on rear flyleaf: Omnes isti summi pontifices a sancto Petro usque ad Sixtum 4m, ccil XXti sex.|From the collection of Henry Probasco, 4 and 12 written on flyleaf.|Forms part of the Henry Probasco Collection at the Newberry Library.

title_as_recorded: Commentary on the Decretales, books I and II
subject_as_recorded: Catholic Church. Decretales Gregorii IX|Canon law--Early works to 1800|Manuscripts, Latin (Medieval and modern)
physical_description: Extent: 206 leaves : paper ; 280 x 200 (195 x 150) mm
note: Manuscript codex.|Title from printed catalog.|Collation: Paper (watermark Y, cf. Briquet 9173-9185), fol. 206; collation impracticable; catchwords mostly removed; traces of alphabetical leaf signatures visible on some rectos, a second sequence by a different hand visible on some versos beginning with Book II.|Layout: Written in 39-44 long lines; frame ruled in very light plummet.|Script: Written in gothic cursiva media; fol. 77r: heading and incipit in lettre bâtarde.|Decoration: Alternating red and blue minor initials.|Origin: Written in France in the middle of the 15th century.|Number 616 in the collection of Joseph Barrois; "616" written on a faded green circular sticker on spine, same number on verso of front flyleaf.|Sold to Lord Ashburnham in 1849, recorded Catalogue of the Manuscripts at Ashburnham Palace (London, 1862); Eighth Report of the Royal Commission on Historical Manuscripts, Appendix, part 3 (London, 1861), p. 96. Sold at Sotheby's 10 June 1901, lot no. 155; "155" written in blue crayon within a circle on verso of first front flyleaf; partially obscured by a clipping from a later English sales catalogue listing this book as item 1150; in the lower right, "494" in pencil with a cipher beneath it.

subject_as_recorded: Catholic Church--Prayers and devotions--Dutch--Early works to 1800|Books of hours--Netherlands--Texts--Early works to 1800|Manuscripts, Dutch
physical_description: Extent: 164 leaves : parchment, illustrations ; 165 x 121 (95 x 71) mm.
note: Manuscript codex.|Title from printed catalog.|Collation: Parchment, fol. i + 164; 14 26 39(+1) 4-58 69(+4) 78 89(+4) 98 109(+5) 11-128 1310 149(+1) 156 169(+9) 17-208 214; all inserted leaves of miniatures; catchwords.|Layout: Written in 21 long lines; ruled in brown ink; prickings visible in outer margins.|Script: Written in hybrida media.|1. Decoration: Six crudely painted miniatures on inserted leaves, each within a silver flamboyant gothic arch frame, three silver balls at the top (partially trimmed: fol. 11v, (Virgin and Child surrounded by four angels); fol. 39v (Gnadenstuhl Trinity); fol. 56v (Christ on the Cross between the two thieves, below, Mary and John the Evangelist, two female figures and a man on horseback); fol. 74v (the infant Jesus between Mary and Ann, the Holy Spirit above); fol. 105v (the Buffeting of Christ); fol. 120v (Pietà); two miniatures removed before fol. 84 and fol. 147.|2. Decoration: Major divisions of the text begin with crude red and blue initials with red and blue flourished touched with green, sometimes yellow, 9-10 lines high. Other divisions begin with red initials with blue tipped with green flourishes alternating with blue initials with red tipped with green flourishes, 3 lines high. Alternating minor simple red and blue initials with the text throughout.|Origin: Written in Holland, probably in Enkhuizen, whose patron saint Gummar is in red in the calendar, after 1471, date of the election of Sixtus IV, to whom text 19 is attributed.|Number 14 from the collection of Henry Probasco.|Forms part of the Henry Probasco Collection at the Newberry Library.

physical_description: Extent: 234 leaves : parchment, illustrations ; 109 x 75 (58 x 34) mm
note: Manuscript codex.|Title from printed catalog.|Collation: Parchment, 234 leaves; 1-26 39(+1) 48(-5) 510(±4) 68 710(+2, 8) 89(+4) 910(+1, 7) 108(+5) 119(+4) 124 139(+1) 14-158 168(-8) 178 1810 1911(+2) 208 214 229(+1) 23-248 2510(+1, 9) 267(+4) 288 2819(+3) 296; catchwords surrounded by four flourished points.|Layout: Written in 15 long lines; ruled in violet ink.|Script: Written in Italian style gothic textualis rotunda media.|1. Decoration: Sixteen full-page grisaille illuminations with pastel blue, pink, and gold (on inserted sheets with no writing on the recto) accompanied by full blue-grey acanthus frame; full matching margins also on the opposite page separated from text by gold and blue baguettes: fol. 13v (the Annunciation, Virgin reads from the banner held by angel), fol. fol. 34v (the Visitation), fol. 48v (the Nativity), fol. 54v (the Annunciation to the Shepherds in the field), fol. 60v (the Adoration of the Magi), fol. 66v (the Presentation in the Temple), fol. 72v (the Massacre of the Innocents), fol. 81v (the Flight into Egypt, Roman columns in the backgroud), fol. 87v (the Coronation of the Virgin), fol. 97v (Jesus raising Lazarus), fol. 148v (Jerome as cardinal writing with left hand on a roll in his study; made from reversed tracing), fol. 170v (King David in prayer, a harp at his side), fol. 194v (the Crucifixion), fol. 203v (Descennt of the Holy Spirit), fol. 208v (the crowned Virgin with Child accompanied by two angels, one playing the harp), fol. 222v (Sebastian).|2. Decoration: gold, black, and white illuminated initials 4 lines high on folios facing the illumations; gold, black, and white dentelle initials on grounds of blue with white patterning throughout; alternating blue initials with red flourishes and gold initials with black flourishes also throughout.|Origin: Written in Flanders, approximately 1475; shows similarity to the style of Willem Vrelent. The manuscript postdates the canonization of Bernardino (1450) mentioned in the calendar.|Unidentified arms painted over original arms and initials; "V. F. V." in lower margin.

physical_description: Extent: 190 leaves : parchment, illustrations ; 105 x 70 (55 x 24) mm
note: Manuscript codex.|Title from printed catalog.|Collation: Parchment, fol. 190; 110 24 310 48 59(+3) 68 79(+6) 88 910 108 1110 129(+5) 139(+3) 1410(lacking 1 leaf) 1511(+2) 168 179(+6) 18-218 2210(lacking 1 leaf) 232.|Layout: Written in 16 long lines; ruled in violet ink.|Script: Written in gothic textualis media.|1. Decoration: Thirteen illuminations on inserted leaves, each accompanied by a blue and gold acanthus spray border decorated with flowers and fruit; matching border on the facing page in the presence of gold, magenta, blue, and green initials, 5 lines high; a fourteenth illumination probably removed after fol. 79.; fol. 80, at the beginning of text, border only without the preceding illuminated leaf: fol. 3v, (the Crucifixion); fol. 4r, (bird in right margin); fol. 14v, (descent of the Holy Spirit depicted within a circular rainbow); fol. 16r, (peacock in right margin); fol. 22v, (Virgin and Child enthroned in the presence of harp-playing angel); fol. 23r, (a bird in the right margin); fol. 35v, (the Annunciation, Divine Light, and rainbow above, white lilies in a vase before the Virgin; fol. 36r, (pheasant in right margin); fol. 56v, (the Visitation); fol. 64v, (the Nativity); fol. 74v, (the Annunciation to the Shepherds in the field); fol. 85v, (the Circumcision); fol. 89v, (the Massacre of the Innocents); fol. 98v, (the Flight into Egypt); fol. 105v, (the Coronation of the Virgin); fol. 122v, (King David in prayer, a harp at his side; above, God within the arc of a rainbow); fol. 123v, (a green bird in right margin); fol. 144v, (the raising of Lazarus); fol. 145r, (bird in the right margin).|2. Decoration: fol.1r, gold, magenta, blue, and green initials 5 lines high accompanied by a full border; sections of text marked by gold dentelle initials with white patterning on grounds of blue and magenta 2 lines high. Blue initials with red flourishes alternating with gold initials with blue-black flourishes.|Origin: Written in Flanders, approximately 1460.|Given to Edward E. Ayer by Martin and Carrie Ryerson, 16 November 1911, on the occasion of Ayer's seventieth birthday. His autograph note is on the second front flyleaf.|"12/69" is written on the verso of the first flyleaf; "Femo" is written on the upper right-hand corner of the third back fly-leaf.

subject_as_recorded: Catholic Church--Prayers and devotions--Latin--Early works to 1800|Catholic Church--Liturgy--Texts--Early works to 1800|Catholic Church. Collectarium|Collects--Early works to 1800|Fasts and feasts--Catholic Church--Early works to 1800|Manuscripts, Latin (Medieval and modern)
physical_description: Extent: 157 leaves : parchment, illustrations ; 225 x 160 (115 x 95) mm
note: Manuscript codex.|Title from de Ricci.|Collation: Thick parchment, fol. 157 (erroneous modern foliation on the first leaf of each quire excludes fol. 1); 18(+1) 28(-1) 3-198 206; traces of leaf signatures visible.|Layout: Written in 15 long lines, calendar in 30 long lines; prickings visible in outer margins.|Script: Written in gothic textualis quadrata formata.|Decoration: fol. 1v: inserted portrait of a male owner wearing armor, in prayer, with a rosary, below crowned Virgin and Child on crescent moon, framed in a flamboyant gothic architectural motif; owner facing his arms with a helmet, mantle, crest, and horrns; legend below reads: Poppo de Wildec dictus Seifert."; fol. 9r: bracket outer rinceaux border with blue, violet, and orange flowers, decorated with small gold disks in clusters of three, an illuminated initials in same colors, 6 lines high; fol. 15v, 49v, 64r: blue and magenta initials on gold grounds, 5 lines high, decorated with Schwarzenberg arms; alternating red and blue initials throughout.|Origin: Written in south Germany in 1427; colophon on fol. 155v indicates a female scribe, but this may indicate the rubricator only, for according to a contemporary note, this book was written by Paul, a Carmelite friar, in 1427 for Poppo de Wildek (see fol. 1r for his arms), who gave this book to a certain Henry: "Anno domini mccccxxvii, frater in Christo perdilectus Poppo de Wildek cognominatus antecessorum more spontali opus hoc in maiorem dei omnipotentis glorioseque virginis Marie honorem manu fratris Pauli Karmelite scribi curauit mihique Henrico in perpetuam fraterne amicitie memoriam kalendis ianuarii [illegible] dedit."

subject_as_recorded: Catholic Church--Prayers and devotions--Early works to 1800|Catholic Church--Liturgy--Texts--Early works to 1800|Books of hours--France--Texts--Early works to 1800|Manuscripts, Latin (Medieval and modern)
physical_description: Extent: 208 leaves : parchment, illustrations ; 163 x 120 (90 x 66) mm
note: Manuscript codex.|Title from printed catalog.|Collation: Parchment (contemporary sewing on some leaves), fol. 208 + i (folios missing after 57(?), 72, 78, and 162); collation impracticable.|Layout: Written in 13 long lines; calendar in 17 long lines; ruled in black and brown plummet and ink.|Script: Written in gothic textualis quadrata media.|1. Decoration: Full page illumination: fol. 16v, addition, (Christopher, symbols of the Four Evangelists in roundels at each corner); Twenty-two half page illuminations in the presence of gold initials 2-3 lines high; the following are in square compartments accompanied by green, blue, orange, and purple acanthus border with floral decoration, vases, and angels in outer margin; fol. 20r, (John the Evangelist with the devil emptying his ink pot); 21v, (Luke sharpening his pen); fol. 23v, (Mark holding a pen in his mouth); fol. 27r, (John the Baptist); fol. 28r, (Anthony); fol. 29r, (Martin with the beggar); fol. 30r, (the Annunciation with the angel holding a scroll, light rays and the dove going from God above to the Virgin); fol. 43v, (the Visitation); fol. 54v, (the Nativity); fol. 57v, (the Annunciation to the Shepherds in the field); fol. 64v, (the Adoration of the Magi); fol. 68v, (the Presentation in the Temple); fol. 87v, (the Virgin (reading) and Child, angel bearing a bowl of cherries, historiated initial of the Virgin); fol. 94r, (David in prayer, historiated initial of a soldier, probably Uriah); fol. 113r, (Michael the Archangel struggling with a demon for the soul of a dead man, historiated initial of a funeral); fol. 160v, (Appolonia). The following have slightly different margins decorated with jesters and animals and are in frames of various shapes: fol. 200r, (Mary Magdalene); fol. 201r, (Nicholas); fol. 202r, (Sebastian); fol. 203r, (Adrien); fol. 204r, (Catherine with a bishop portrayed in the margin). Some miniatures are beginning to flake from the leaves. Miniatures removed after fol. 72 and 78.|2. Decoration: Minor magenta, gold, and blue dentelle initials with similar line fillers; sprigs of floral decoration extend from larger initials.|Origin: Written in France in the first half of the 15th century, quite possibly in northeastern France.|In the first half of the 16th century, this book belonged to Jean Nicolas, Commissaire examinateur au Châtelet, rear flyleaf verso: Ces heures apartiennent a moy, Jehan Nicolas, examinateur et commissaire ordinaire de par le roy notre sire ou Chastellet de Paris, demourant rue Montellerie, d'achapt par luy faict a douze solz tournois.|Former owner's inscription 16th or 17th century: Confitebor tibi domine in toto corde meo.|Rear flyleaf contains epistolary pen exercise, 16th century, including: Henry Roy de France. A nos ames et leaulx conseillers, les gens de nostre court de parlement de Bretagne ..."|Former owner's inscription fol. 160r: Anno domini millesimo quingentesimo quinquagesimo octauo. Donna a Orleans l'an de grace.

subject_as_recorded: Catholic Church--Prayers and devotions--Early works to 1800|Catholic Church--Liturgy--Texts--Early works to 1800|Books of hours--Italy--Texts--Early works to 1800|Manuscripts, Latin (Medieval and modern)
physical_description: Extent: 216 leaves : parchment, illustrations ; 73 x 54 (38 x 26) mm
note: Manuscript codex.|Title from printed catalog.|Collation: Parchment, fol. 216 (foliated 1-61, 63-217); 12 212 313(+1) 410(-5 and 6) 5-710 812(+4) 913(+3) 10-1110 1212 13-1410 1512 16-2110 222; catchwords present; leaves signed alphabetically, partially trimmed.|Layout: Written in 13 long lines; ruled in green ink.|Script: Written in Italian gothic textualis formata.|1. Decoration: Two inserted miniatures in early 16th century Venetian style: fol. 15v, (the Annunciation); fol. 81v, (the Massacre of the Innocents (compline)). A modern hand on fol. 1v has attributed these to Giulio Clovio, but they are not likely his. Probably to be attributed to a follower of Cima da Conegliano.|2. Decoration: Blank leaves within the text intended for illuminated miniatures and incipits. Border decorations in blue, green, and red ink of architectural motifs, with many birds and a rabbit present. Blue initials with red flourishes alternating with red initials with blue flourishes throughout, 2 lines high at beginning of sections of text, 1 line high within the text.|Origin: Written in northern Italy, possibly in Padua, note presence of Justina, Anthony, and Prosdocimus in the calendar; the calendar also suggests Franciscan affinities.|"Siena" written in modern pencil in upper margin of fol. 216r; fol. 1v, old sticker, probably of a dealer, with number "1354" and "tra" in black ink and "rax" in red ink; "17" written in pencil on the flylead itself.

title_as_recorded: Bartholomew of San Concordio alias of Pisa, Summa de casibus conscientiae
subject_as_recorded: Casuistry--Early works to 1800|Conscience--Early works to 1800|Christian ethics--Catholic authors--Early works to 1800|Canon law--Early works to 1800|Manuscripts, Latin (Medieval and modern)
physical_description: Extent: 371 leaves : parchment ; 158 x 110 (102 x 57) mm
note: Manuscript codex.|Title from printed catalog.|Collation: Parchment, fol. 371 (original arabic foliation in red ink); 110(entirely removed) 2-3910 401(a single leaf, matches catchword on fol. 380v); vertical catchwords preceded and followed by a dot.|Layout: Written in 31 lines in two columns beginning on the second ruled line; special column for the gloss; ruled in plummet.|Script: Written in semi-gothic textualis media with occasional use of humanistic d, g, and long terminal s.|Origin: Written by friar Gabriel de Prato Alboyno in the Franciscan convent of Sant' Angelo in Milan in 1466. "Hanc summam pisanam per m inceptam in loco s. Mariȩ de angelis apud Mediolanum foras muros portȩ Cumanȩ condito expleui in eodem loco, ego frater Gabriel de Prato Alboyno ordinis minorum professor anno domini millesimo quadringentesimo sexagesimo sexto, viiio kalendas septembris, id est xxvo die augusti hore xxma anno ȩtatis meȩ xxxvo, mense decimo, conuersionis uero ad religionem anno xv et mense viio, cuius summe usus est michi fratri Bernardino de Martinengo concessus per reverendum patrem fratrem Ludouicum a Turri vicarium provincie Brixie" ("summe" through "Brixie" written by a humanistic hand before 1498 over the latter portion of the original inscription which is erased and illegible). (fol. 369r)|Number 2 from the Collection of Henry Probasco.|A reader's note written by the same hand on a small rectangular scrap of paper was found loose in the book and is now on file at the Newberry.|Forms part of the Henry Probasco Collection at the Newberry Library.

physical_description: Extent: 229 leaves : parchment ; 278 x 200 (197 x 110) mm
note: Manuscript codex.|Title from printed catalog.|Collation: Parchment, fol. i (paper) + 229 + i (paper); 1-288 298(-6, 7, 8); vertical catchwords.|Layout: Written in 27 long lines beginning on the first ruled line; ruled in hard point.|Script: Written in humanistic textualis formata.|Decoration: Texts 1 and 2 and each book of text 3 commence with a gold initials with white vine stem decoration on grounds of blue, red, and green accompanied by gold radiating disks 6-8 lines high; fol. 25r: white vine stem decoration extended to form inner border, two putti bear arms with a decorative pattern in lower margin accompanied by floral decoration of different hues than those of the decoration in the rest of the book and, therefore, possibly a later addition.|Origin: Written in the middle of the 15th century by Masullus in the Castel dell'Ovo in Naples for the library of King Alfonso the Magnanimous, King of Naples and Aragon, signed on fol. 229, "... laus tibi summe pater atque fili Quique procedis simul ex utroque Spiritus sancte deus unus idem Laus tibi semper Praecipiti ventus quum strauit turbine malos Et summa evertut classis carchesia regis Arnaldi edicto, codex perfectus in Acre Ovi perque manum scriptus fuit iste Masulli."|In 1858, in the library of Don Miguel de Mayora, Vice-Consul of Mexico in Barcelona, recirded by Volger, "Plato's Republik." Subsequently in the library of Don Luis Mayora, recorded by Beer, "Handschriftenschätze."|Number 22 from the collection of Henry Probasco.|Forms part of the Henry Probasco Collection at the Newberry Library.

note: Manuscript codex.|Title from printed catalog.|Collation: Parchment, fol. i + 159 + i (flyleaves are old pastedowns; rear flyleaf inverted); 1-198 208(8 stub only); vertical catchwords.|Layout: Written in 33 long lines beginning on the first ruled line; ruled in hard point.|Script: Written in humanistic textualis formata slightly cursive; corrections in headings by the scribe; sporadic marginal notes by several hand, 15-17th century, some of these in violet by the scribe to serve as index notes.|Decoration: fol. 1r: gold initial decorated with white vine stem on ground of green, red, and blue, historiated with a bust of Petrarch, accompanied by full white vine stem and laurel border 14 lines high; two putti bear coat of arms in lower margin, another above in upper right; three similar gold initials decorated with white vine stem 7 lines high on fol. 38 and 87, 4 lines high on fol. 88r; minor blue rustic capital initials with red flourishes and red initials with violet flourishes throughout.|Origin: Written in Lombardy before 1464; fol. 1r, putti bear arms of Borromeo family and initials "CO FI" for Comes Filippus = Filippo Borromeo (died 1464).|Armorial bookplate of Conte Archinto (Milan).

physical_description: Extent: 98 leaves : parchment ; 315 x 225 (235 x 166) mm
note: Manuscript codex.|Title from printed catalog.|Collation: Parchment, fol. i + 98 + i (folation of 15th or 16th century, mostly arabic, on verso of each folio in upper margin center); 1-812 92; catchwords present.|Layout: Written in 45 lines in two columns; ruled in pen; prickings visible in outer margins.|Script: Written in gothic textualis media; additions in Italian hybrida currens; marginal index in Italian cursiva media.|Origin: Written in Germany in the middle of the 14th century; additions also written in Germany in the 14th century; marginal index written in Italy in the early 15th century.|Former owner's inscription (14th century) fol. 98v: Liber fratris Philippi de Alemania [or Alcania]; followed by a cipher (perhaps) a shelf mark); below, an inscription in Italian textualis rotunda, 14th century: Amor amoris Anthonio de Pol de Zotte.|Former ower's inscription (16th century) on front flyleaf verso in very black ink: Vetustissimum dictionarium latinum aliisque linguis insertum.|Front flyleaf is a notarial diploma dated 25 August 1401 recording a transaction in which a piece of land is sold for 16 ducats to a woman from Vinenza, living in Chioggia: In nomine dei eterni amen. Anno ab incarnacione domini nostri Yesu Christi millesimo quadrigentesimio primo, die vigesimo quinto mensis Augusti, indicione nona, Clugie. Testificor ego Laurencius Panerio, curie Clugie decanus, quod eodem predicto die, de mandato egregii et sapientis viri domini Nicolai Foscari, honorabilis potestatis Clugie ..." Signed by two notaries, Iohannes de Andre and Petrus de [illegible], a notarial signum below.|Inverted drawings (Italian, approximately 1400) of a man and a woman, labeled Pretus [sic] and Margaretha with a pen trial in the same hand (not inverted), "Pater noster in omni omnium tribulacione et a[n]gustia et in omni" on fol. 98v.|Second rear flyleaf verso, an inverted inscription worn and now illegible.

title_as_recorded: Book of hours, use of Rome (Order of Saint Francis)
subject_as_recorded: Franciscans--Prayers and devotions--Early works to 1800|Catholic Church--Prayers and devotions--Early works to 1800|Franciscans--Liturgy--Texts--Early works to 1800|Catholic Church--Liturgy--Texts--Early works to 1800|Books of hours--Italy--Texts--Early works to 1800|Manuscripts, Latin (Medieval and modern)
physical_description: Extent: 225 leaves : parchment, illustrations ; 166 x 160 (98 x 68) mm
note: Manuscript codex.|Title from printed catalog.|Collation: Parchment, fol. 255; a leaf removed after fol. 14; collation problematic; catchwords present surrounded by a variety of decorative pen flourishes; leaves signed alphabetically with roman numerals sometimes in red, mostly trimmed; guides for rubicator present.|Layout: Written in 16 long lines, calendar in 18 long lines; ruled in lead point.|Script: Written in Italian gothic textualis rotunda media.|1. Decoration: Historiated initials: Eleven similar initials 5-7 lines high: fol 16v, (the Nativity); fol. 27r, (the Annunciation to the Shepherds in the Field); fol. 32r, (the Presentation in the Temple); fol. 36v, (the Adoration of the Magi); fol. 40v, (the Flight into Egypt); fol. 45r, (Christ and the Doctors); fol. 52v, (the Baptism of Christ); fol. 78r, (King David in prayer); fol. 101v, (the Crucifixion); fol. 106r, (funeral Mass, participants in white habits); fol. 138r, (Madonna and Child). Twelve Milanese style historiated magenta initials in the same style on gold grounds 4 lines high depicting a male figure engaged in the activities of the four seasons: fol. 3r, January (seated before a fire); fol. 4r, February (pruning); fol. 5r, March (blowing a double horn); fol. 6r, April (smelling flowers); fol. 7r: May (with a falcon); fol. 8r, June (cutting grain with a sickle); fol. 9r, July (thrashing grain); fol. 10, August (making a barrel); fol. 11r, September (picking grapes); fol. 12r, October (picking fruit); fol. 13, November (drawing wine); fol. 14, December (preparing the carcass of an animal). A miniature probably removed after fol. 19r. Larger initials accompanied by bracket borders decorated with red, blue, and magenta flowers. Each smaller initial accompanied by sprigs of gold ivy decoration.|2. Decoration: Minor red initials with violet flourishes alternating with blue initials with red flourishes.|Origin: Written in central Italy, probably in Gubbio, in the first half of the 15th century, probably for a member of the Franciscan order, as indicated by the calendar and the formulas of confession; Ubaldus of Gubbio listed twice in the litany; Marianus and Jacobus, patrons of the cathedral in Gubbio, also in the litany; other saints of Umbria and central Italy in the litany and the calendar.|Front flyleaf inscription "Ludovicus Bertuvey," possibly 18th century.

note: Manuscript codex.|Title from printed catalog.|Collation: Parchment, fol. i + 222 + i; 18(-7, 8 missing) 2-910 108 1110 1210(-10) 13-1610 1710(-10) 188(leaves removed from the end and reinserted so that the sewing precedes 7-8) 19-2210 242 (an undetermined number of leaves missing with loss of text); quires 16-19 numbered i-iiii in lower right margin of the recto of the first leaf.|Layout: Written in 28 lines in two columns; calendar ruled for 36 long lines; text ruled for 28 lines in two columns in ink; fol. 196-222, entirely reruled in red ink for musical notation.|Script: Written in Italian gothic textualis rotunda formata.|1. physical_description: Extent: 319 leaves : paper ; 220 x 155 (210 x 145) mm
note: Manuscript codex.|Title from printed catalog.|Collation: Paper (watermarked with tête de beouf with six-lobed flower, cf. Briquet 14800 sqq., and croix latine, not in Briquet), fol. 319 (foliated 2-299 in contemporary arabic numerals with no leaf foliated 141, 222, 279, 288, 289, two leaves foliated 244 and 226; four unnumbered leaves after fol. 163; single unnumbered leaves of varying shape after fol. 10, 67, 126, 132, 136, 159, 198, 208, 217, 224, 227 (loose), 231, 241, 250, and 287; lacking first leaf); collation impracticable but a portion of the text composed of single sheets instead of quires.|Layout: Written in 36 to 57 long lines; some sheet rules in large squares.|Script: Written in gothic cursica currens of uneven quality, probably by one hand.|Origin: Written in Erfurt by Johannes Hagen, prior of the Carthusian monastery of Mons salvatoris, as indicated by rewritten fragments inserted following fol. 197 and 226, in 1460, this date appearing on fol. 155 and 278; choice of text corresponds closely to the inventory of study notes left by Johannes Hagen. Cf. Klapper, Johannes Hagen, 2:124-125. This codex recorded as "C142" in the late 15th century inventory of the Carthusian Library of Erfurt, Mittelalterliche Bibliothekskataloge Deutschlands 2:428-429.

note: Manuscript codex.|Title from printed catalog.|Collation: Parchment, fol. ii + 202 + ii (foliated 1-204); 16 24(-4) 310(1, a numbered leaf, stub only with possible loss of text) 4-1310 1418 1510(1 removed with possible loss of text) 16-1910 2010(-10) 2118; catchwords surrounded by pen flourish designs.|Layout: Quire 1 written in 32 long lines; quires 2-19 in 21 lines in two columns; quire 20 in 50 long lines; ruled in pen.|Script: Written in Italian gothic rotunda formata.|Decoration: Historiated magenta, yellow, blue, and green acanthus leaf initials on gold grounds 4-5 lines high extended to form blue and green acanthus spray outer bracket borders decorated with pink, blue, and yellow flowers: fol. 140v (three apostles), fol. 143r (a Carthusian friar in prayer, his face badly worn), fol. 155r (Andrew), fol. 181r (Jesus with a closed book); fol. 1r, 17v, 18r, 67r, and 129r-185, numerous similar initials with blue and magenta interiors decorated with gold dentelle patterning, many also decorated with flowers 3-8 lines high; those with flowers in the interior extended to form piece acanthus spray borders, also decorated with flowers; fol. 162v, an initial with a gold chalice and white host in the interior; red and blue minor initials with intricate flourishes in red, blue, violet, and painted gold throughout; minor initials washed with yellow.|Music: Notation on six red four-staves which do not follow original ruling.|Origin: Written in Florence, approximately 1408, date on which the feast of Anne was accepted by the Carthusian monastery of San Lorenzo in Galluzzo near Florence.|Brief description of this book, possibly by a dealer, dated 1805; below, "Cosimo duc dei Cosmè Ferrarese."|Formerly number 39 in the collection of Henry Probasco.|Forms part of the Henry Probasco Collection at the Newberry Library.

note: Manuscript codex.|Title from printed catalog.|Collation: Parchment, last quire paper, 482 leaves (foliated a-i (modern); 1-10, 16th century probably from another codex; 11-109 (modern) and every tenth leaf, Medieval roman foliation 1-350, beginning on what would be fol. 110 of the preceding numerical sequence; final folios unnumbered; no. fol. 176, teo fol. 235, and no fol. 275 and 302); 110 (-1) 210 310(-1 with loss of text) 4-610 78 8-1110 1212 13-3110 328 3312 34-4710 484 4914(-4) 506; catchwords surrounded by four strokes except quire 2 which is in a decorated rectangle.|Layout: Written in 29 lines in two columns (quire 2 ruled for and written in 25 lines); ruled in lead point.|Script: Written in Italian gothic textualis bt several hands with occasional evidence of humanistic influence; ink varies from brown to very black.|Decoration: fol. 1, pink, blue, and green initials, historiated with what appears to be David holding a psaltery, 7 lines high; bracket floral border in same colors, in lower margin a cherub astride an erased olive wreath intended for a coat of arms; fol. 1 (second numerical sequence), magenta, blue, and green initial, historiated with a half length portrait of the Virgin(?) holding a book, 7 lines high; full border with olive leaf wreath for arms containing some gold paint, but mostly blank; fol. 11v-109v, red initials with violet flourishes alternating with blue initials with red flourishes; minor simple red and blue alternating initials; fol. 1-355 (second numerical sequence), red initials with violet flourishes (toward the very end blue flourishes) and blue initials with red flourishes only; minor initials touched with yellow in the second half of manuscript.|Origin: Written in central Italy, the decoration suggests in or near Florence, approximately 1463-1465, dates cited in calendrical tables.|Erased colophon in red ink under second column, fol. 358v, illegible under ultraviolet light.|Contemporary ex libris "Iste liber est mei Silvestrie Ioanis s[er] Francisci de Anglario."|Number 7 from the collection of Henry Probasco.|Forms part of the Henry Probasco Collection at the Newberry Library.

note: Manuscript codex.|Title from printed catalog.|Collation: Parchment, fol. 223 (six unfoliated leaves followed by leaves with original foliation in red roman numerals: 2-9, 11-145, 147-158, 160-221); 18(7-8 stubs only) 210(-1, -10 with loss of text) 3-1510 1612(-6 with loss of text) 178(7 stub only with loss of text) 18-2210 2310 +1; catch words begin with quire 4, preceded and followed by a point.|Layout: Written in 31 long lines; canon written in 16 long lines; prickings in outer margins; ruled in brown ink.|Script: Written in Spanish textualis rotunda formata; vertical line enders characteristic of Spain.|Decoration: fol. 153r, 172r, 176v, 183v, bracket acanthus margins in green, orange, violet, blue, and gold; fol. 153r, green dragon in upper margin, exotic birds in lower margin; fol. 172, face of a man in lower margin; fol. 176v, parrot in upper margin, exotic bird and purple dragon below; fol. 183v, exotic bird and infant in left margin; fol. 210, modern pen floral decoration added; deep blue initials with red flourishes alternating with red initials with violet flourishes.|Music: Noted music.|Origin: Written in Spain after 1461, as indicated by transalpine feast dates of calendar, script, and border decorations, for a Carthusian convent, as indicated by the calendar. It is possible that this book comes from the convent at Aniago, founded in 1441 by Mary of Aragon, wife of John II of Castile.|Number 40 from the collection of Henry Probasco.|Former owner's inscriptions: fol. 203r, a sixteenth-century corrector has added to the Suffrage to All Saints, "adque (sic) beati Brunonis confesoris tui;" fol. 203v, in the Votive Mass, "Pro gernalis," the same corrector has added "Et famulos tuos, papam, regem, reginam et principes nostros cum prole regia et nos ab omni adversitate custodi ..." This is the same hand that added text no. 18.|Forms part of the Henry Probasco Collection at the Newberry Library.

physical_description: Extent: 234 leaves : paper ; 238 x 215 (205 x 137) mm
note: Manuscript codex.|Title from printed catalog.|Collation: Paper (watermark of tête de cerf, cf. Briquet 15557, and an undetermined watermark not in Briquet) ; fol. 234 (original arabic foliation partly visible) ; 1-212 310 4-612 76 (catchword on fol. 76v matches text on fol. 77v; text on fol. 77r and part of 77v canceled by the scribe) 8-2012 212 ; catchwords throughout ; guide letters for the rubricator present; fol. 223v and 225r, space for an illumination left blank.|Layout: Written in 28-35 lines; framed ruled in pencil for two columns.|Script: Written in northern hybrida media with Italian traits; minims of the first written line hung from the upper rules line; fol. 5v, the scribe, in writing the text of Ptolemy, has lapsed into a northern gothic textualis media.|Origin: Written in Italy (the paper suggests northern Italy) by a northern scribe in the middle of the 15th century.|Marginal index notes and running headings by the scribe and rubricator, additional finding notes, glosses, and pointing hands added by several humanistic hands of the second half of the 15th century and the first half of the 16th century.|According to the information reproduced on the bookplate of Edward E. Ayer, Henry Stevens (or his son Henry Newton Stevens) purchased this manuscript for the Ptolemy collection from Quaritch between 1868 and 1898, when it was purchased by Mr. Ayer.

title_as_recorded: Book of hours, use of Rome, prayerbook of Margaret of Croy
subject_as_recorded: Catholic Church--Prayers and devotions--Early works to 1800|Catholic Church--Liturgy--Texts--Early works to 1800|Books of hours--Belgium|Books of hours--Netherlands|Manuscripts, Latin (Medieval and modern)
physical_description: Extent: 212 leaves : parchment, illustrations ; 179 x 129 (105 x 70) mm
note: Manuscript codex.|Title from printed catalog.|Collation: Parchment, fol. 1 + 212 + 1 leaves; 1-26 38(-1 unidentified leaf) 44 5-148 155(+5, 16th century?) 16-288 292 (2 is pastedown).|Layout: Written in 19 long lines; ruled in violet ink with change in shade beginning on fol. 109r; calendar ruled for 33 lines; prickings visible in outer margins.|Script: Written in gothic textualis quadrata media by two hands.|1. Decoration: Six inserted full-page miniatures, of which five are in the style of Otto von Mordrecht, accompanied by full rinceaux border with floral decoration: fol. 7r (the kiss of Judas, rabbit in outer margin, bird in lower margin); fol. 8r (Christ before Pilate); fol. 9r (the scourging of Christ); fol. 10r (Christ bearing the Cross); fol. 11r (Descent from the Cross, by another artist, bird in upper margin, dog in lower margin, fantastic bird with a human head in outer margin); fol. 12r (the Entombment); fol. 13r (not inserted but with similar border decoration, the Coronation of the Virgin; above, an angel blowing a horn bearing a pennant with the five wounds of Christ, a fantastic animal in the upper margin, a centaur in the lower margin blowing a horn bearing a pennant with a white cross on a red ground, another centaur in the outer margin).|2. Decoration: Thirteen half-page miniatures by at least two artists accompanied by full rinceaux borders of a different style, fantastic creatures of various sorts and blue initials on grounds of gold and magenta: fol. 20v (the Crucifixion with Mary and John); fol. 22r (Pentecost); fol. 24r (the Annunciation); fol. 36r (the Visitation); fol. 43v (the Nativity); fol. 47 (the Annunciation to the Shepherds in the Field); fol. 50r (the Adoration of the Magi); fol. 53r (the Massacre of the Innocents); fol. 56r (the Presentation in the Temple); fol. 61r (the Flight into Egypt); fol. 65r (Death of the Virgin; Peter dressed as a Dominican); fol. 71r (King David in prayer, a harp at his side); fol. 83r (funeral scene in a church, two black monks in attendance).|3. Decoration: Two half-page miniatures accompanied by full acanthus spray margins, magenta initials on gold grounds: fol. 109r (Gnadenstuhl Trinity, a centaur in outer margin, a fantastic dragon-bird in lower margin); fol. 151r (Margaret of Croy kneeling befire the Pietà).|4. Decoration: Thirty-eight blue and magenta historiated initials on gold grounds 5 lines high: fol. 174v (Michael, John the Baptist); fol. 175r (Peter); fol. 175v (Paul); fol. 176r (Andrew, John the Evangelist); fol. 176v (James); fol. 177r (all apostles, Stephen); fol. 177v (Lawrence); fol. 178r (Cornelius, George); fol. 178v (Christopher); fol. 179r (Quirinus, Sebastian); fol. 179v (Erasmus); fol. 180r (the ten thousand martyrs); fol. 180v (all martyrs, Martin); fol. 181r (Anthony the Abbot); fol. 181v (Theoboldus, Nicholas); fol. 182r (Francis in a brown habit); fol. 182v (Hubert, all confessors, in the front row, a Franciscan friar in a brown habit); fol. 183r (Mary Magdalene); fol. 183v (Catherine, Barbara); fol. 184r (Agnes); fol. 184v (Apollonia); fol. 185r (Margaret, Elizabeth); fol. 185v (Ursula with her cloak above the eleven thousand virgins); fol. 186r (Cunera); fol. 186v (Dorothy, all virgins); fol. 187r (All Saints); fol. 187v (Sebastian).|5. Decoration: fol. 1r-107r, gold dentelle initials with white patterning on grounds of blue and magenta with pieces of floral decoration mark sections of text; within text, alternating blue initials with red flourishes and gold initials with black flourishes; fol. 109r-211r, blue and magenta dentelle initials with white patterning on gold grounds 4 lines high with pieces of rinceaux border mark beginnings of major texts; gold dentelle initials with white patterning on grounds of blue and magenta mark shorter texts; gold initials with red flourishes within texts.|Origin: Original manuscript (fol. 1-6 and 13-107) written in Flanders, probably in Bruges, approximately 1430; inserted miniatures on fol. 7-12 resemble those produced in Utrecht approximately 1430; fol. 109-221, added approximately 1450, probably in Utrecht, presence of Cornelius and Cunera in the suffrages; this section added for Margaret of Croy, daughter of Antonoie of Croy (1385-1475), wife of Henry of Montfort (Holland).

subject_as_recorded: Catholic Church--Liturgy--Texts--Early works to 1800|Catholic Church--Prayers and devotions--Early works to 1800|Graduals (Liturgical books)--Italy--Texts--Early works to 1800|Graduals (Chants)--Early works to 1800|Sequences (Music)--Early works to 1800|Gregorian chants--Early works to 1800|Manuscripts, Latin (Medieval and modern)
physical_description: Extent: 1 choir book (197 leaves) : parchment ; 536 x 392 (390 x 249) mm, in binding 608 x 421 mm
note: Manuscript music.|Title supplied by cataloger.|Collation: Parchment, fol. 197 (contemporary foliation in red i-xxxiii, xxxv-lxxxiii, lxxxi-lxxxiii, lxxxxv-clxxxx (numbers i, xli, and l in a second hand); foliated in brown ink 1-83, 85-196 (includes rear pastedown); foliated with stamp 1-195); 1-310 410(-4) 5-710 85(+5) 9-1910 203(+3); lacking 6 leaves between quires 8 and 9, 1 leaf in later hand inserted; prickings visible in outer margin.|Layout: Written in 36 long lines; ruled in red.|Script: Written in textura rotunda.|Decoration: Three large historiated initials in blue, green, and pink ink and gold leaf, each with a large foliate border, fol. 40r historiated "R, "Christ emerging from the tomb with a dragon and fish forming the bow of the R, sleeping soldiers at the base of the tomb, cityscape in the background; fol. 73v historiated "V," apostles viewing the ascension; fol 102r historiated "C," monstrance on an altar with two angels kneeling before the altar. Incomplete historiated(?) initial, fol. 5r "D" in blue, green, and pink ink with gold leaf, center empty; fol. 86r illuminated "V" on parchment cut out (possibly from leaves now lacking, main decorative style consistent with original decoration) and pasted on, a later hand has attempted to touch up the decoration and hide the pastedown. Fol. 84r decorative "S" with foliate elements in a later hand in green, purple and orange ink on a blue background, with orange and yellow border. Alternating red and blue initials with blue and red pen-flourishing respectively; smaller red and blue initials with purple and red pen flouishing respectively; yellow color washed litterae notabliores.|Music: Red 4-line staves with black square notation, six staves per page. Throughout later revisions have been made to gradual, Alleluia, and tract versicles, and Alleluia melismas; revisions include abbreviating melismas by scraping away notes and including red notes to indicate abbreviations; sequences "Victime paschali laudes," "Veni Sanctus Spiritus," and "Lauda sion" have been scraped and rewritten in measured notation with changes in clef and inclusion of accidentals and fermatas; fol. 86v two paper pastedowns have been added to erase notes; fol. 109r tempo markings "largo" and "primo te[m]po" have been added in a later hand; the inclusion of fermatas and tempo markings suggest that at least some of the revisions were made in the 18th century or later. Folio 84, the introit and psalm for Pentecost mass, have been completely rewritten in square notation and the leaf tipped in.|Origin: Probably written in Italy, 16th century.

"Acabose este lib[r]o dia de purificacion de N[ost]ra Señora scribiolo el padre Juan d[e] Lamota an[n]o 1615." (fol. 97r)|Former owner's inscription: Mr. Wm. subject_as_recorded: Catholic Church--Prayers and devotions--Early works to 1800|Catholic Church--Liturgy--Texts--Early works to 1800|Books of hours--France|Manuscripts, Latin (Medieval and modern)
physical_description: Extent: 15 sheets : parchment, color illustrations ; 165 x 119 (180 x 135) mm in box 385 x 295 mm
note: Manuscript leaves.|Title supplied by cataloger.|Fifteen leaves from a Book of hours each with a border, text segment, and illumination. Five of the miniatures are modern forgeries (possibly 19th century): Annunciation to the Shepherds (leaf 4); The Nativity (leaf 5); Presentation in the Temple (leaf 7); Coronation of Virgin (leaf 13); The Trinity (leaf 15). The forgeries are painted on thick modern vellum with the 15th border and text segment pasted on.|Script: Written in gothic textura.|Decoration: Fifteen illuminations by at least two medieval illuminators and one modern illuminator: leaf 1: Four Evangelists; leaf 2: Annunciation; leaf 3: Visitation; leaf 4: Annunciation to the Shepherds; leaf 5: Nativity ; leaf 6: Adoration of the Magi; leaf 7: Presentation in the Temple; leaf 8: Flight to Egypt; leaf 9: Virgin and Child with Patron Portrait; leaf 10: Office of the Dead; leaf 11 King David; leaf 12: Pentecost; leaf 13: Coronation of the Virgin; leaf 14: Crucifixion; leaf 15: Holy Trinity;|Origin: Written in France, probably in Rouen, at the end of the 15th century.|Each leaf attached to protective board and place in a box with three leaves to a box.
