note: Manuscript music.|Title supplied by cataloger.|Collation: Parchment, fol. 134 (foliated in black ink i-cxv); 110(+1, +2) 28 310(-2) 4-88 96 10-148 154 166(+5, +6) 176 186(-6); leaves mended by sewing and pasted on parchment.|Layout: Written in 4 long lines, ruled in lead point; fol. 5v-5v, 7v-15v, 21r-22v, 25v-26v, 28v-36v, 47v-54r, 62r-69v, 78r-79r, 81r-88r, 93v-94v, 99v-107v written in 12 long lines, frame ruled in black ink; fol. 115r written in 20 long lines, fol. 117v, 119v-121v written in 17 long lines, frame ruled in black ink; fol. 1v and 2v frame ruled in red; parchment tabs; directions to rubricator occasionally visible.|Script: Written in southern textura.|Decoration: 7 large decorated initials, fol. 124v foliate "E" in green, yellow and red with a cherub and lion wearing a red cardinal's hat on a blue and red background of skulls, in an ornamental yellow and orange border; fol. 126v foliate "M" in blue, red, yellow and orange with a column with a dolphin at its base, within a red border; fol. 127v blue "A", left leg includes a papal tiara, miter, galero, and a biretta, the right leg depicts a pile of seven skulls surmounted by a crown, within a red border; fol. 130r "M" with gold cornucopias and grotesque in green, blue, red, and white, within red border; fol. 132v foliate "E" in blue, pink, red, yellow, and green, within a red border; fol. 133v foliate "I" in blue, red, pink, and yellow on a purple and white background, within a red border; 2 large red and white initials on a blue background (fol. 3v, 27r); large, medium and small initials in red on a blue background with white floral designs, blue on a red background with gold floral designs, blue on gold or yellow background with red floral designs, one red on gold background with red floral designs; large red initial with elaborate blue and red pen flourishing (fol. 123r); large blue and red initial with elaborate blue and red pen flourishing extending into outer and lower margin; large black calligraphic initials with elaborate pen flourishing in purple, red, and blue (fol. 122r-123v); large black strapwork initials; red initials with single line black border (fol. 115r-117v).|Music: Red 5-line staves with black square and measured notation; four staves per page; fol. 116r-117r seven staves per page; fol. 118r-118v, 123r-123v five staves per page. B-flats added throughout in a later hand(?). Hymns "Tibi Christe," "Christe sanctorum," "Urbs Jerusalem," and "Angelaris funda" and two settings of the antiphon "Stetit angleus" in measured notation. Fol. 43v text specific to the feast of St. Martin has been erased with indication for omitting that part of the antiphon "O beatum pontificum" (fol. 42v-44v).|Origin: Written in Spain 17th century; leaves 122-123 from 15th century.

subject_as_recorded: Motets|Hymns, German|Manuscripts, German|Manuscripts, Latin (Medieval and modern)
physical_description: Extent: 2 part books (2 volumes ([1], 84 leaves)) : manuscript ; 14 x 17 cm.
note: Part books, one for bass part of 63 compositions and the other for cantus part of 22 other compositions, comprised of motets and some hymns for mixed voices.|At head of title: Fasciculus.|Composers of most works in the bass part book are identified within the text and include Ludwig Daser, Sixtus Dietrich, Jakob Gerhart, Jacob Handl, Valentin Haussmann, Gregor Lange, Orlando di Lasso, Thomas Mancinus, Jacob Meiland, Philippe de Monte, Jacob Regnart, Antonio Scandello, Johann Sigfrid, and Johannes Wessalius. The compositions in the cantus part book are unattributed.|The bass part book was probably produced in Saxony, possibly in Dresden. The cantus part book is written in a different hand and was possibly produced in Saxony during the 17th century.|The first 55 compositions in the bass part book are numbered 1-55; the last 8 in this book and all of the compositions in the cantus part book are unnumbered. Lacking compositions 18, 19, and 38 and part of 37.|All leaves after the title leaf in the bass part book are numbered in pencil 1-66 in a modern hand; the leaves in the bass part book are similary numbered 67-84. Content is written on both sides of the leaves except for leaves 66v and 67, which are blank.|Faint armorial stamp and shelf marks "R 15791" and "R 15570" on title page of bass part book and leaf 79r of cantus part book.

note: Manuscript music.|Title devised by cataloger.|Collation: Parchment, fol. 197 (numbered intermittently in pencil 1-197); 17(+1) 27(-1) 3-88 98(-6, -7) 108 118(-1) 128(-1, -3) 13-228 238(-1, -8) 2411(+1, -3, -11) 258 268(-8) 275(+1, -4).|Layout: Written in long lines; ruled in lead point; guide letters occasionally visible.|Script: Written in textura in 3 hands. Hand A, fol. 1-169; hand B, fol. 170-193; hand C, fol. 194-197.|Decoration: Six large illuminated initials with marginal trompe l'oeil borders, fol. 1r blue "D" on brown background historiated with Mary standing in a garden holding an open book, border in gold with pink, blue, and red flowers, a bird and a bee; fol. 31v gold "Q" on brown background, filled with a plant with blue and white flowers, border in green, gold, and brown with flowers and strawberries; fol. 48v gold "V" on blue background historiated with the Assumption of Mary, border with architectural elements; fol. 58r blue "P" on brown background, historiated with a saint (Bernard?) in white robes holding a crozier, kneeling before a seated Mary holding the baby Jesus, border in gold, blue, and orange, with white knot-work decoration; fol. 146v blue "A" on gold background with red flowers, gold border with red, blue, and pink flowers, with a bird and moth; fol. 155v blue "E" on brown background historiated with a bishop holding a crozier and an open book, with landscape behind, architectural border in brown and blue; black initials with brown pen-flourishing, highlighted with yellow and red, many with faces, grotesques, and other drolleries including depictions of monks, nuns, bishops, and a warthog playing bagpipes, several initials include text in scrollwork (fol. 167r signed "Cornelius"); fol. 194r orange, yellow, blue, and green initial "H" with foliated elements and small marginal border with face of a wild man; fol. 196r blue and white initial "V" on light purple background with foliate elements in green and yellow; fol. 197 black initials with yellow, green, and light purple foliate elements, one with scrollwork with text; fol. 43v, red initial with blue pen-flourishing; alternating red and blue initials (in 3 hands).|Music: Red 4-line staves with black square notation; 10 staves per page; B-flats and E-flats occasionally indicated (in a later hand?); several staves throughout include small G clefs, often in combination a C clef.|Origin: Written in Flanders, approximately 1500; probably Cistercian due to the prominence given to the feast of St. Bernard.|Inscription, fol. 162v: Bonesse.|Initials cut out from fol. 32, 36, 52, 62, and 107.

Attribution to the Genoese chartmaker Battista Agnese questioned as "doubtful" in Herbert Raup Wagner, "The manuscript atlases of Battista Agnese" in Bibliographical Society of America. Papers 25 (1931): 42-45, 53, and 102.|Similar to another, more finished, unsigned, and undated manuscript portolan atlas at the Newberry Library (Ayer MS map 12).|Pen-and-ink and paint (blue, green, red, yellow). Burghly [?]" (i.e. William Cecil, Lord Burghley?) noting that he was given the atlas by Charles Howard, Earl of Nottingham and chief English admiral during the Spanish Armada of 1588; inscription, apparently by Pierre Esprit Radisson, French explorer and fur trader in North America, noting that the atlas was given to him by Charles Bayley, first governor of Hudson's Bay; inscription by "Morpin [?]" noting that Radisson gave him the atlas in 1675; and note dated 1680 (or 1690?), also by Morpin, stating he returned the atlas to Radisson. See Catalogue of geography, voyages, travels, history of America, Africa, Australasia and Asia ... (London: [Bernard Quaritch], 1899), catalogue 188, no. 907. See also transcription of the French glosses, made in 1974 by Claude Perrault, in the Map Information File).|Owned by George Wilbraham (bookplate, 19th cent.?)|Forms part of the Edward E. Ayer Manuscript Map Collection (Newberry Library).

title_as_recorded: Liber de moribus hominum et officiis nobilium
subject_as_recorded: Chess--Early works to 1800|Social classes--Early works to 1800|Conduct of life--Early works to 1800|Manuscripts, French
physical_description: Extent: leaves 96r-153v : parchment, illustrations ; 340 x 238 (200 x 150) mm
note: Manuscript component part.|Listed as text 2 of "Jacques Legrand, Livre de Bonnes Meurs; Jacques de Cessoles, Liber de Moribus (in French)" (Case MS 55.5) in Catalogue of the pre-1500 western manuscript books at the Newberry Library, pages 97-98.|Title devised by cataloger.|Layout: Written in 31 lines in 2 columns; ruled in violet ink.|Script: Written in lettre bâtarde formata; headings in red in script of text. The script is typical of that used in the most deluxe books of the Burgundian court at the time of Philip the Good and Charles the Bold. Consult Clemens, R. Introduction to Manuscript studies for more information on script.|Decoration: half-page illuminations: fol. 96r: Jehan Ferron presenting his translation to Bertran Aubert; fol. 100v: an enthroned king; one-column illuminations approximately 12 lines high: fol. 102v: a queen; fol. 106v: a judge; fol. 109r: a knight in full armor; fol. 114r: a royal officer; fol. 120v: the first pawn or peasant; fol. 122v: the second pawn, a carpenter; fol. 124r: the third pawn, a notary; fol. 128r: the forth pawn, a merchant banker; fol. 131r: the fifth pawn, a physician; fol. 134r: the sixth pawn, an innkeeper; fol. 136r: the seventh pawn, a city watchman; fol. 138r: the eighth pawn, a messenger; fol. 140v: a teacher explaining the game of chess. These miniatures have been attributed by Friedrich Winkler to the Master of Anthony of Burgundy in a letter dated October 27, 1951 in the files of the Newberry and in Die Flämische Buchmalerei, page 261; fol. 96r and 100r, ornate gold dentelle initials with white patterning on grounds of blue and orange-res 2-4 lines high accompanied by margins with floral decoration in the presence of half-page illumination; similar dentelle initials 2 lines high and bracket acanthus spray margins in the presence of smaller illuminations; each chapter begins with a standard gold dentelle initial with white patterning on grounds of magenta and blue; alternating blue initials and paragraph marks flourished with black.|Origin: Written and decorated in Flanders before 1478 for Wolfart de Borsele.

subject_as_recorded: Jerome, Saint, -419 or 420--Correspondence|Christian saints--Correspondence--Early works to 1800|Manuscripts, Latin (Medieval and modern)
physical_description: Extent: 338 leaves : parchment ; 340 x 232 (225 x 130) mm
note: Manuscript codex.|Title from printed catalog.|Collation: Parchment (palimpsest, southern preparation, 14th century), fol. i + 338 ; 12 28 3-1110 128 13-3510 ; catchwords surrounded by a varying pattern of points and flourishes.|Layout: Written in 40 long lines beginning on the first ruled line; prickings visible in outer margin, on fol. 90, two rows of prickings present; ruled in hard point.|Script: Written in Italian hybrida media by several very similar hands, with trailing terminal "s", humanistic form of the "g", occasional humanistic use of the "e" with cedilla for "ae" diphthong, and occasional use of the ampersand; the life of Jerome (fol. 3) written in rustic capitals; the "Sepulcri epythaphium (fol. 3) written in humanistic cursiva; headings written in violet (humanistic) on fol. 51r-69v and in red (gothic) elsewhere, all in script of text; incipits of the first letter of each book written in rustic capitals; space for Greek left blank.|Decoration: fol. 3r: illuminated purple and dull gold initial decorated with green, blue, and purple acanthus spray on a checkered ground of gold, purple, and blue, 14 lines high; the acanthus spray extends into a full gold ivy border decorated with red, blue, and green tulip-shaped flowers, a peacock, putti, a wolf, and various fantastic animals; in lower margin, a miniature of Jerome in a red robe writing on a scroll in his study with book cupboard; text, initial, and illumination framed by a gold compartment filled with red, green, and blue; red initials with blue flourishes and blue initials with red flourishes at the beginning of each book after the first, 8-10 lines high; two initials also have pale yellow flourishes; smaller blue initials with red flourishes alternating with red initials with blue flourishes at the beginning of each epistle.|Origin: Written in Ancona by several scribes including Johannes Petrus Mathei de Anchona, signed and dates April 23, 1459 on fol. 337v; in 1460, Nicolas of Ancona presented this book to the Franciscan convent of Ancona: fol. 337v, "Has sacras epistolas deuotissimi Yieronimi sacrarum scripturarum grecarum et ebreicarum interpetris, cuius laboribus ecclesia erudita extitit, Nicolaus Ankonitanus, legum doctor, conlocauit in sacrastia sancti Francisci de Ankona conscrictas et alligatas. Iussitque et mandauit inde nullo pacto admoueri posse per quemcumque, dominiumque et proprietatem earundem sibi et suis heredibus reseruauit, utendas et fruendas fratribus et aliis quibuscumque reseruauit; alienationem uero earundem omnino prohibuit interminatione diuini iuditii pro anima sua et filiorum suorum et Baldassarris sui consobrini. Ad laudem summi dei, amen. Anno domini 1460, in die natiuitatis domini hic posite fuerunt."|Two unidentified coats of arms on fol. 3r.|Formerly owned by George Reid with his bookplate and, annotated in black ink, "bought in Rome by George Reid"; sold by Reid in 1904 to C. W. Dyson Perrins.|Armorial bookplate of C. W. Dyson Perrins and blue and white circular "Perrins Collection" sticker with "65" written in black ink. Listed as no. 65 in Descriptive catalogue of illuminated manuscripts in the library of C. W. Dyson Perrins. Exhibited by Dyson Perrins at the Burlington Fine Arts Club in 1908, the catalog description (no. 198) tipped onto a modern front flyleaf.

physical_description: Extent: 73 leaves : paper, illustrations ; trimmed to 201 x 145 (150 x 103) mm
note: Manuscript codex.|Title from printed catalog.|Collation: Paper (two types intermixed, some quite light and shiny, some yellowed and fuzzy, the latter having a simple Latin cross watermark, cf. Briquet, 5590, visible on fol. 39 and 40), fol. ii + 73 ; collation not practicable.|Layout: fol. 1r-66v: ruled in pen and hard point for two columns; fol. 5r-31v: all in 38-46 lines in 2 columns beginning, in this section only, on the first ruled line; fol. 67r-72v: written in approximately 34-47 long lines, frame ruled without horizontal ruling after the first leaf for long lines|Script: fol.1r-4v: written in lower Rhine Valley hybrida media incorporating some Italian traits by Adam de Wesalia, O.P.; fol. 5r-31v: in a similar script by another hand; fol. 67r-72v: written in gothic cursiva media; marginalia in gothic cursiva currens; headings in humanistic rustic capitalis on fol. 5r-31v and in Italianate textualis rotunda on fol. 1r-5r and 32r-66r; text 5 added in humanistic textualis.|Decoration: Red initials and paragraph marks.|Origin: Written in Rimini by Adam de Wesalia, O.P., a German scribe with Italian training (signed fol. 3v, 53v, and 65v), dated 1454-1456; other portions of the text also reflect a mixture of Northern and Italian traits, with Italian traits particularly strong on fol. 5r-31v.|Bookplate of Louis H. Silver.|Possibly from the library of the Dominicans of Verona; fly leaf, "Iste liber est conuentus ueronenisis ordinis fratrum praedicatorum in primo deposito a sinistris 19" written in Italian humanistic cursiva, 15th century. This ex libris may be fraudulent by Guillaume Libri.|In the library of Marchese Paolino Gianfilippi (Verona) at the end of the 18th century; purchased in 1843 for the collection of Joseph Barrois, , his number 426 written on green circular sticker on spine; sold to Lord Ashburnham; sold at Sotheby's, June 10, 1901, lot no. 582 ("582"" written in blue crayon within a circle on front pastedown), clipping from the catalog tipped to flyleaf, entry for this book partially visible on the verso; in the 20th century, in the library of Sir Israel Gollancz.

physical_description: Extent: 285 leaves : parchment ; trimmed to 373 x 255 (230 x 148) mm
note: Title from caption on fol. 1r.|Manuscript codex.|Title from printed catalog.|Collation: Parchment (southern preparation), fol. 285 (fol. 1-240, original arabic foliation in red; fol. 241-284, modern pencil, last leaf unnumbered) ; 1-2810 296 (-6) ; catchwords surrounded by four flourishes with many minor variations.|Layout: Written in 37 long lines, beginning on the second ruled line,|Script: Written in humanistic textualis formata by more than one scribe; fol. 201r-217v, quotation marks frequently used; accents present, a distinction made between the form of accent mark used for the tonic syllable and that used to denote the letter "i"; headings in red in rustic capitals and in script of text; upper margins, running headings in red in script of text; Greek words generally omitted in text, written by the scribe in Latin transliteration in margin with Latin interlinear translations; some Greek words added in the blank spaces in 15th-century.|Decoration: fol. 1r, gold initial historiated with Jerome as a cardinal in his study, decorated with white vine stem on a blue and pink ground 14 lines high in the presence of a full white vine stem border, decorated with gold on a ground of pink and blue; lower margin center, within a roundel, Christ with cross standing in the tomb; lower margin left, half portrait of Justina; lower margin right, half portrait of Prosdocimus? as bishop; fol. 147v, 187v, and 200v, gold initial with white ivy stem decoration 10 lines high in the presence of an outer white ivy stem decoration 10 lines high in presence of an outer white ivy stem margin; the border on fol. 187v has human head and a stag's head at the extremities; white vine stem initials 4-6 lines high throughout.|Origin: Written in illustrated in Italy at Padua, approximately 1450 for the library of the monastery of Santa Giustina.|Formerly in the monastery library of Santa Giustina: fol. 1r and 284v, written in humanistic textualis media: "Iste liber est monachorum congregacionis sanctȩ Iustinȩ ipsi monasterio Sanctȩ Iustinȩ patauii deputatus," with number "325" and pressmark "B 15"; recorded as no. 325 in library catalog dating from 1453-1484 in Padua, Museo Civico.|Formerly in the library of Lawrence W. Hodson with printed label on front pastedown: "From the library of Lawrence W. Hodson, Compton Hall near Wolverhampton".|Armorial bookplate of C. W. Dyson Perrins and round black sticker with "86" written in pen. Listed as no. 86 in Descriptive catalogue of illuminated manuscripts in the library of C. W. Dyson Perrins.|Sold at Sotheby's, December 3-5, 1906, lot number 300; sold by Quaritch in 1909 to C. W. Dyson Perrins; sold at Sotheby's, December 1958, lot number 29.

physical_description: Extent: 175 leaves : parchment ; 293 x 161 (238 x 123) mm
note: Manuscript codex.|Title from printed catalog.|Collation: Parchment, 175 fol.; 1-168 176+1 18-228; quires numbered within red and black rectangular frames in the lower left margin of the verso of the last leaf, 1-3 numbered "vi q"-"viii q", quire 6 numbered "viiii q", quires 13-15 numbered "iii q"-"v q;" quires 1-21(except quire 17) numbered in hard point by a later medieval hand x-xxi.|Layout: Written in 31 long lines, ruled in hard point with single boundary lines, except for quire 17 which is ruled in pen and written beginning on the first ruled line (except on fol. 129); fol. 135 ruled in pen in two columns but ruling ignored by the scribe; prickings occasionally visible on outer margins.|Script: Quires 1-16 and 18-22 written in caroline textualis media with incipient word separation with syllables often written as separate words; at least five hands, Hand A appears to have written quires 1-3, 6-7, 13-15, 20 (beginning on fol. 157), and 21; Hand B has written quires 4-5, 16, and 22; Hand C has written quires 8-11 (to the top of fol. 81v); Hand D has written quire 11 (fol. 81v-88v only); Hand E has written quires 18-20 (fol. 152-157 only); occasional portions of text erased and rewritten in 12th century; quire 17 written in gothic textualis media, 14th century.|Decoration: fol. 1r-57r, pen initials, some with incipient floral decoration and touched with orange at the beginning of each text, 2-8 lines high; fol. 27v, an initial decorated with a human face, touched with orange, 2 lines high; fol. 81v-96r, initials within the text touched with orange.|Origin: Written in southwestern France, probably at the abbey of Saint Pierre de Moissac in the first half of the 11th century; the script shape and prominence given to Saint Peter suggest the identity of the abbey. ""Südliches Frankreich, X. Jh., 2. Hälfte"--Bischoff, B. Katalog der festländischen Handschriften des neunten Jahrhunderts, page 196.|Titles rewritten in margin in 11th, 12th, and 14th century, apparently to serve as finding aids; many corrections in the text and in the margins, 11th and 12th centuries; marginal numbering of lessons, mostly contemporary but occasionally dating from 12th century.|Purchased by Sir Thomas Phillipps in Paris, approximately 1835.|In the library of Jacques Rosenthal (catalogue no. 83, p. 53-56); inherited by Bernard Rosenthal.|Formerly no. 1326 in the library of Sir Thomas Phillipps.|Former shelfmark: Phillipps MS 1326.|Stamp of Sir Thomas Phillipps.

physical_description: Extent: leaves 1r-95v : parchment, illustrations : 340 x 238 (200 x 150) mm
note: Manuscript component part.|Listed as text 1 of "Jacques Legrand, Livre de Bonnes Meurs; Jacques de Cessoles, Liber de Moribus (in French)" (Case MS 55.5) in Catalogue of the pre-1500 western manuscript books at the Newberry Library, pages 97-98.|An abridged translation and adaptation of the author's Sophologium, parts ii and iii (books 6-10).|Title from printed catalog.|Layout: Written in 31 lines in 2 columns; ruled in violet ink.|Script: Written in lettre bâtarde formata; headings in red in script of text. The script is typical of that used in the most deluxe books of the Burgundian court at the time of Philip the Good and Charles the Bold. Consult Clemens, R. Introduction to Manuscript studies for more information on script.|Decoration: half-page illumination fol. 5v: God the Father presiding over the fall of the angels; one-column illuminations approximately 12 lines high: fol. 37v: elevation of the Host; fol. 44v: an enthroned king with his court; fol. 58v: a rich man dispensing alms; fol. 78r: a men on his deathbed with attendants. Fol. 5r, ornate gold dentelle initials with white patterning on grounds of blue and orange-res 2-4 lines high accompanied by margins with floral decoration in the presence of half-page illumination; similar dentelle initials 2 lines high and bracket acanthus spray margins in the presence of smaller illuminations; each chapter begins with a standard gold dentelle initial with white patterning on grounds of magenta and blue; alternating blue initials and paragraph marks flourished with black.|Origin: Written and decorated in Flanders before 1478 for Wolfart de Borsele, his arms painted on lower margin and on fol. 5r and 96r without the insignia of the Order of the Golden Fleeces to which he was elected at the thirteenth chapter of the order, Bruges, 1478.|Former owner's inscription, fol. 1r, "Ex libris D. Baliar [?] Bousers [?] 1562" crossed out.

note: Manuscript codex.|Title from printed catalog.|Collation: Parchment, fol. 1 + 231 (a small unnumbered leaf tipped in after fol. 12; first 10 leaves unfoliated; 1-124 foliated in contemporary roman numerals, verso and recto in red ink; 11 leaves foliated in modern pencil 1-11; 2nd medieval foliation in roman numerals, verso and recto, 1-88 with no folios 81, 84, or 85, 2 folios 82) ; 110 2-168 176 186 (-1 with loss of text) 196 20-228 2310 24-2810 (last leaf serves as rear pastedown) ; folios signed, partially trimmed.|Layout: Written in 36 lines in 2 columns; fol. 3r-6r written in 22 lines in 2 columns; ruled in brown ink.|Script: Written in hybrida media; fol. 3r-6r written in hybrida formata; headins in script of text.|Decoration: 5 historiated initials in the Proper of Time only: fol. 1r, 12 lines high (pink initial on a gold ground, historiated with the Coronation of the Virgin); fol. 9r, 8 lines high (blue initial P on a gold ground, historiated with the Nativity); fol. 77r, 10 lines high (blue initial R on a gold ground, historiated with the Resurrection); fol. 88r, 8 lines high (initial U, historiated with the Ascension); fol. 92r, 8 lines high (initial S, historiated with Pentecost); in each instance, accompanied by a gold and red baguette and pieces of blue and gold acanthus spray border in the upper and lower margins; alternating blue and red flourishes in Proper of Saints.|Origin: Written probably in Ghent, approximately 1470, by the Brethren of Jerome, as suggested by the binding and the calendar of the diocese of Tournai, for the use of a secular church; Proper of Saints and choice of sequences are to be found in printed Tournai missals.|Armorial bookplate, gold-stamped leather of Eduard Hailstone.|Former owner's inscription: fol. 1r: rubbed out, visible under ultraviolet light: "Missale istud reuenit ad mensam sancti spiritus in ecclesia sancti Michaelis grandauensis." former_owner_as_recorded: Philip, Duke of Burgundy, 1396-1467|Holford, Robert Stayner, 1808-1892|Holford, George Lindsay, 1860-1926|Rosenbach, A. S. W. 1876-1952|Silver, Louis H
physical_description: Extent: 43] leaves : parchment, illustrations ; 382 x 283 (210 x 155) mm
note: Manuscript codex.|Title from verso of leaf [42].|Translated from the Latin: Speculum humanae salvationis. The Latin text is usually attributed to Ludolphus de Saxonia. The French translator is not identified. The present version (chapters 1-42 only) is an abridgement of the original.|The text is probably the same as that of Ms. fr. 1363 in the Musée Condé, Chantilly. The physical characteristics of this ms. are so similar to those of the Condé ms. as to make it seem probable that the two mss. were made at about the same time, possibly in the same scriptorium. The miniatures are similar in subject but quite different in execution. Cf. Litz-Per-drizet, Speculum humanae salvationis, v.1, p. 105 (no. 242) and p. 331 (no. 242); F. Gruyer, Chantilly, Le cabinet des livres, manuscrits, v.1, p. 128-130 (no. 139); and J. Meurgey, Les proncipaux manuscrits à peintures du Musée Condé, p. 138-144, and plates XCVI-XCVIII.|Layout: Written in 28 lines in double columns; ruled in violet ink; catchwords.|Script: Written in lettre bâtarde.|Decoration: 168 square miniatures; some fully colored, some partly grisaille, perhaps unfinished, within gold frames at the head of each column, following the iconographic conventions for chapters 1-42. Blue, green, and pink acanthus spray margins under the outer column of the verso of each folio in the presence of standard gold dentelle initials with white patterning on grounds of magenta and blue 4 lines high. Each initial extended to form a gold baguette in the outer left margin. Similar minor dentelle initials throughout.|Origin: Copied and decorated in Flanders, approximately 1455.|Formerly in the library of Philip the Good of Burgundy, recorded in the inventories of 1467 and 1485. Recorded in the Burgundian library until 1577.|Formerly in the collection of Robert S. Holford and privately sold by his son, Sir George Holford to A.S.W. Rosenbach of Philadelphia.|This manuscript is probably the one sold at the Crozet sale to Techner. Consult The sale catalog, page 2 (no. 8) with Colomb de Batines' note.|Bookplate of Louis H. Silver.

physical_description: Extent: 79 leaves : paper, illuminations ; 260 x 200 (143 x 116) mm
note: Manuscript codex.|Title from printed catalog.|Collation: Paper (water damage severe toward end; fol. 76-79, folios reset on modern paper), fol. i + 79 + i ; 110 (-9, stub only) 21 (a single leaf with catchwords on verso) 3-810 910 (-10) ; horizontal catchwords surrounded by 4 fleur-de-lys-type flourishes.|Layout: Written in 25 long lines; ruled in pencil.|Script: Written in northern European lettre bâtarde; headings in red in script of text; occasional marginal notes in Italian humanistic cursiva.|Decoration: fol. 1r: gold dentelle initial with white patterning on a ground of green, blue, and red 5 lines high; discrete full border of blue, green, and red acanthus spray decorated with radiating gold disks; gold dentelle initials with white patterning on grounds of green and blue 4 lines high at the beginning of each chapter, some decorated with a trace of acanthus spray bearing radiating gold disks; alternating red and blue minor initials throughout.|Origin: Written in Italy by a scribe trained in northern Europe, after January 31, 1483, date on which Oliviero Carafa became bishop of Santa Sabina (Rome).|Unidentified cardinal's arms, fol. 1r, placed beneath a bishop's miter, on either side, the initials "O" and "F"; these arms are not those of Oliviero Carafa.|Former owner's signature, front pastedown, of Henry Cestole, 18th-century.

physical_description: Extent: 170 leaves : parchment, illustrations ; 204 x 140 (105 x 70) mm
note: Manuscript codex.|Title from printed catalog.|Collation: Parchment, fol. iii + 166 + 1 ; collation impracticable ; alphabetical leaf signatures mostly trimmed.|Layout: Written in 19 long lines, calendar in 33 lines; ruled in violet ink.|Script: Written in gothic textura.|1. Decoration: 27 full-page miniatures on inserted leaves accompanied by two different border schemes: Border A: blue, green orange acanthus spray with gold ivy stem frame (English in appearance); Border B: blue, gold, violet acanthus spay with floral decoration including thistles, violets, and strawberries, very similar to the Bruges borders associated with Willem Vrelant. Each border accompanied by initials in matching colors 5 lines high.|2. Decoration: 27 full-page miniatures: fol. 7v, border A (Christ with angles playing music on an instrument belonging to the lute family and a harp on either side); fol. 14v, border B (Gnadenstuhl Trinity); fol. 17v, border B (John the Baptist); fol. 19v, border B (George); fol. 21v, border B (Christopher); fol. 23v, border B (Martyrdom of Thomas à Becket); fol. 25v, border B (Anne,the Virgin and Child); fol. 27v, border B (Mary Magdalene); fol. 29v, border B (Catherine); fol. 31v, border B (Barbara); fol. 33v, border B (Margaret); fol. 35v, border A (Jesus in the Garden of Gethsemane); fol. 42v, border B (Kiss of Judas); fol. 54v, border B (Christ before Pilate); fol. 58v, border B (the Flagellation); fol. 61v, border B (Christ carrying the Cross); fol. 64v, border B (the Crucifixion); fol. 67v, border B (Descent from the Cross); fol. 70v, border B (the Entombment); fol. 77v, border B (the Coronation of the Virgin); fol. 86v, border B (Mary ascending the steps at the Temple); fol. 90v, border B (Adam and Eve in the Garden below the Arbor Vitae, the devil as a female-headed snake entwined around the tree); fol. 99v, border A (Last Judgement); fol. 115v, border B (funeral service by priests and monks); fol. 136v, border B (God the Father receiving two naked souls); fol. 148v, border B (Man of Sorrows, behind him the instruments of torture); fol. 155v, border B (Jerome at his desk).|3. Decoration: 9 historiated initials 5 lines high: fol. 91r, border B (three crosses); fol.91v, 2 initials, border B (Jesus and the stigmata on right hand accompanied by a bracket left type B border); fol 92r, two initials, border B (stigmata on left hand and the wounds of Christ accompanied by a bracket left type B border); fol. 92v, two initials (stigmata on the left foot and stigmata on the right foot); fol. 93r, two initials, border B (Pietà and John the Evangelist accompanied by a bracket left type B); fol. 91v, 92r, 92v, 93r bracketed left border of type B.|4. Decoration: Gold, blue, and magenta dentelle initials throughout; guides for the insertion of miniatures written in lower margins of the verso of the preceding folio; that on fol. 18v indicates a miniature of Saint John the Evangelist, now lacking.|Origin: Written and decorated in Bruges, approximately 1455, for the English market as indicated by the phrase, "secundum consuetudiem Anglie" in fol. 36r. Saints and selections of texts are typically English. Texts 11, 12, 14, and 20 in masculine form.|Former owners: William Gonstone and Thomas Mildmay.|Former owner's inscription: "The namys of the children of Wilham Gonstone and Benet his wif of the perisshe of Saincte Donistones in the est as hereafter ffolowith"; list on flyleaf i, first entry: "Friday the xxiiii day of November being Saincte Clementis Day and the xxiiii yere of King Henry VIIthe ...", last entry written in the "Sixt yere of our sayde souuerayne lorde King Henry the Eight."|Former owner's inscription listing the children of Tomas Mildmay; births recorded in various hands to 1607 including the name of Walter Mildmaye.|Heraldic ownership mark drawn in pen in lower margin of fol. 8r, possibly that of Mildmay.|Stubbs following fol. 166 indicate traces of other ownership notes, now removed.|Erasures, maskings, and scratching out of references to Thomas à Becket and indulgences date from English Reformation.|Ownership attributed to Baron Fitzwalter (-1608) by Kessler, French and Flemish illuminated manuscripts from Chicago collections, not confirmable from the manuscript.

physical_description: Extent: 26 unumbered leaves : illustrations ; 15 x 21 cm
note: Title from dealer's description.|Calligraphic manuscript written by scribe, Matthieu Le Febvre, for Nicolas Clement, in Antwerp from 1598 to 1600.|Full alphabet of calligraphic exemplars showing different styles of lettering. Each leaf has a large decorated initial followed by a passage of text and full alphabets in capital letters and in lower case letters. Several leaves are signed and dated between 1598 and 1600.|Dedication leaf: Le livre d'exemples si ie scavoye Aucunement parler, ie respondroye Quand on demande qui m'est possedant, Nicolas Clement suis appartenant. Anno, MDXCviij.|Colophon in mirror writing: Dieu est mon droict qui nous faict droit Escrit par moy Matthieu Le Febvre D Anvers, ce premier jour du mois d'Apuril En l'an de nostre Seigneur Seize cents.|Book-labels of Leonard and Lisa Baskin.

note: Ms. codex.|Title from printed catalog.|Collation: Parchment, fol. 201; 112 28 36 4-138 1410 234 24-258.|Layout: Written in 17 long lines; ruled in violet ink.|Script: Written in lettre bâtarde.|Decoration: Thirty one half page illuminations simply executed in a style reminiscent of Jean Bourdichon accompanied by elaborate full borders of blue, red, and green acanthus on grounds of gold, red, and black, often compartmentalized in intricate geometrical designs. Schwarzii, Prof. P. Altorf.|Forms part of the Henry Probasco Collection at the Newberry Library.

Katalog der festländischen Handschriften des neunten Jahrhunderts, page 196.|Fol. 1r, "liber de origine mortis humane" written in a contemporary hand, rubbed out and written again by an 18th century hand which also wrote a summary table of contents on the first front flyleaf. A more detailed table of contents by another modern hand on the second front flyleaf.

subject_as_recorded: Catholic Church--Prayers and devotions--Latin--Early works to 1800|Cistercians--Liturgy--Texts--Early works to 1800|Catholic Church--Liturgy--Texts--Early works to 1800|Missals--Texts--Early works to 1800|Mass--Prayers and devotions--Early works to 1800|Manuscripts, Latin (Medieval and modern)
physical_description: Extent: 208 leaves : parchment ; 316 x 218 (225 x 150) mm
note: Manuscript codex.|Collation: Parchment, fol. i + 208; 18 28(-1) 3-58 610(-1) 76 810 98(-1) 10-168 178(-1) 184 19-258 264.|Layout: Written in 32 long lines beginning on first ruled line; fol. 140r-144r in 19 long lines; fol. 204r-207v in 30 long lines beginning on the second ruled line; prickings visible occasionally on outer margins; ruled in lead.|Script: Written in protogothic textualis; fol. 140r-144r in gothic textualis formata clearly modeled on a proto-gothic exemplar, not especially use of half-unical "d"; fol. 204r-207v in gothic textualis; additions in various proto-gothic scripts.|Decoration 1: Historiated initial: fol. 140v (Christ on the cross in green, red, brown, and magenta).|Decoration 2: Decorated initials: (a) Large white vine stem initials in red, blue, orange, purple, and green; (b) 4-10 line smaller vine stem initials; (c) 1-7 line initials in the same colors throughout; (d) German style red initials in three different inks and hands dating from 12-14th centuries.|Origin: Written probably in southern Germany in the second half of the twelfth century before 1173, date of the canonization of Thomas à Becket (added in the Proper of Saints, fol. 170r). Presence of Kilian (fol. 176r) in the Proper of Saint indicated diocese of Würzburg. Addition of Masses for Bernard and rubric on fol. 199r indicate a Cistercian abbey. Date of Mass for the foundation of the church inserted in the Proper of Saints suggests that this missal was prepared for use in the Abbey of Erbach (founded 1135).|Belonged to Cistercian Abbey of Hohenfurt in Bohemia in 1282 or shortly thereafter; see dated note verso of flyleaf containing numerous Bohemian names: "Poizlau seruus domini, Wokkonis de Crumwenaw homicidium Hainrico iudici in Altouado a prefato Poizla eidem impositum in presencia domini Wokkonis et domini Adam abbatis ... in Altouado ob remedium domini Witigonis de Crumwenaw ... misericorditer relaxauit ... Acta sunt hec anno domini 1282." An excerpt follows inn which Peter Woks I of Rosenberg grants privilege to the abbey "quod nulli liceat gladium ... super aliquam personam nudam extrahere." Kilian struck out (fol. 176r) at this time as no longer relevant. Additions: Elizabeth (fol. 1v) 13th century, Adalbert (fol. 106r) 13th century, and Wenzelaus (fol. 124r and 205r) 14th century, indicate presence in Bohemia.|Recto of flyleaf, pen trails "domine et michi," etc., largely effaced even under ultraviolet light, may be partially in Czech.|Fol. 141r-142r, headings and marginal notes added in formal humanistic cursive in violet ink, 16th century; fol. 39r, in lower margin, "C + M + B +, 1556." This codex still in Hohenfurt in 1891, recorded "Xenia Bernardina", vol. 2, pt. 2, pages 192-193 codex LXXV (old shelf-mark on spine of this manuscript).|Listed in Emile Hirsch Sales Catalogue, "Valuable Manuscripts of the Middle Ages Mostly Illuminated" no. 16, plate 14.

note: Manuscript codex.|Title from printed catalog.|Collation: Parchment, fol. 58 + ii; 1-68 710. Seven diagrams on irregular inserts contained in first text. Modern foliation 1-66 includes diagrams on one flyleaf. Quires numbered in lower margin on recto of first leaf with late medieval arabic numerals|Layout: Written in 32 long lines; prickings in outer margins; ruled in hard point; fol. 62v-63v in double columns.|Script: Written in caroline textualis.|Decoration: Orange-red diagrams forming part of the original codex; fol. 65v, diagram in red. Gloss joined to text by complex emblematic tie notes. Fol. 6r, St. Gall neumes present in the gloss. White ivy stem initials drawn in orange, 4-8 lines high, on grounds of blue and green. Orange-red headings in mixed uncials and rustic capitals.|Origin: Written in Austria in the late 11th or early 12th century.|Former owner's inscription: Bibliothecae Admontis.|Cited in the catalog of 1380, "Mittelalterliche Bibliothekskataloge Österreichs" 4:62, line 1. Recorded in the 19th century manuscript catalog of Admont Library, Wichner, "Catalogus Admontensis", page 207, number 409. Sold in 1937 to L. and A. Brecher (Brünn).

physical_description: Extent: 206 leaves : parchment, illustrations ; 210 x 157 (125 x 80) mm.
note: Manuscript codex.|Title from printed catalog.|Collation: Parchment (southern preparation), fol. 206 + i (medieval roman numeral numbering of distinctiones partly visible in upper left and right) ; 1-212 3-1910 2012 ; leaves signed a-e, a-d, and i-iiii in red and blue ink; first leaf after the midsection of the quire marked with a plus sign.|Layout: 36-38 lines in double columns; ruled in pen.|Script: Written in southern gothic textualis.|Decoration: Four magenta initials on gold grounds 10 lines high historiated in magenta, blue, and white at beginning of each book: fol. 1r: Peter Lombard as bishop, teaching; fol. 3r: Ecclesia et synogoga; fol. 59v: creation of Eva; fol. 112v: the Nativity; fol. 153r: Holy Communion. Iconography in the tradition of Paris and northern France. Cf. Branner.|Origin: Written in southern France in the middle of the 13th century.|Former owner's inscription in 15th century Italian humanistic cursiva: Hec linea bis sex ducta indicat mensuram domini nostri Iesu Christi, sumpta est autem Constantinopoli ex aurae cruce ad formam corporis Christi. Pro lv f.|Former owner: Henry Probasco.|Forms part of the Henry Probasco Collection at the Newberry Library.|Text accompanied by substantial glosses, portions rubricated, written by at least three different 13th century southern hands, supplemented by distinctiones, 13th century, and by brief notes, 13th-14th century. Flyleaf contains a table of distinctiones with references to the text by two southern hands, the smaller of which is quite possibly one of the hands of the gloss.

note: Manuscript codex.|Title from printed catalog.|Collation: Parchment; 18(-1) 2-118 1210(-1 leaf, binding too tight to specify) 13-148 1514 16-208.|Layout: Written in 25 long lines; ruled in brown ink with double column reserved on outer margins for larger initials.|Script: Written in gothic textualis formata.|Decoration 1: fol. 160v: full page illumination of the crucifixion on a tree with a pelican in her piety, a lion breathing on her cubs, and Mary and John the Evangelist, in gold, red, violet, blue, and green.|Decoration 2: fol. 1r: King David elevates his soul, 17 lines high (advent); fol. 9r: the Nativity, 10 lines high; fol. 11r: Virgin and Child, 15 lines high; fol. 128v: Infant Jesus between Mary and Joseph with an altar below, the letter S as a green dragon, 8 lines high; fol. 136r: Christ at the resurrection, 8 line high (very deteriorated).|Decoration 3: Decorated illuminated initials: fol. 73r: D as a blue dragon, 8 lines high; fol. 107r: T historiated with two gold dragons, 12 lines high; fol. 14: E, 9 lines high.|Decoration 4: Flourished initials: alternating red and blue initials, flourished in red throughout, 2-3 lines high; minor initials in red, characteristically German.|Sewing holes visible around miniatures and initials, evidence of previously attached protective silk curtains.|Origin: Written in Germany in about 1250, Saints of Proper and illuminations suggest Rhine valley, possibly Cologne.|Marginal suffrage to the Virgin added 15th century (152v-153r); collects added in German script, 17th century.

subject_as_recorded: Bible--Translations into Latin--Early works to 1800|Bible--Manuscripts, Latin|Manuscripts, Latin (Medieval and modern)
physical_description: Extent: 585 leaves : parchment ; 139 x 93 (91 x 64) mm
note: Ms. codex.|Title from printed catalog.|Collation: Parchment, fol. 585 + i; 1-924 1014 11-1924 2022 2126 2222 2322 (-20, 22) 2424 2626; catchwords mostly trimmed.|Layout: 47 lines in two columns; separate column prepared for gloss; fol. 508r-582v: 3 columns prepared for points of reference; ruled in plummet.|Script: Written in gothic textualis media.|1. Decoration: Historiated initials: 17 blue initials on magenta grounds alternating with magenta initials on blue grounds, historiated miniatures in red, blue orange, gray, white and gold, 8-10 lines high, frequently extended to form partial borders: fol. 1r; Jerome: fol. 4v: the creation in five panels, the expulsion from the garden, Christ seated, the crucifixion between Mary and John the Evangelist with a Franciscan friar kneeling below, in all 47 lines high; fol. 71v: Moses watching Aaron placing tablets in the Ark; fol. 109r: Elkanah and wives at the alter; fol. 123r: David ordering the execution of Amalekite ; fol. 161v: pedigree register; fol. 205r: Tobit and swallow; fol. 209r: Judith beheading Holofernes; fol. 220v: God observing Job on the dung heap and the devil; fol. 231r: King David with his harp; fol. 258r Solomon instructing Rehoboam; fol. 300r: two men sawing Isaiah's head with a two-man saw; fol. 387r: Hosea and Gomer; fol. 409v: beheading of an idolatrous Jew; fol. 433v: the Tree of Jesse, 23 lines high; fol. 480v: Paul bearing a sword; fol. 510v: the Ascension.|2. Decoration: Initials of the same size and color decorated with dogs, centaurs, a merman, hybrid dragon monsters (some with human heads), birds with human heads, and other hybrids. Attributed to the early Aurifaber atelier in Paris. Cf. Branner, R. Manuscript painting in Paris.|3. Decoration: Red and blue flourished initials frequently extended to form borders to the left of one or the other written columns.|Origin: Written in Paris in the 2nd half of the 13th century.

physical_description: Extent: 123 leaves : parchment ; 260 x 168 (204 x 120) mm
note: Manuscript codex.|Title from printed catalog.|Collation: fol. 123; 1-48 56( -1) 6-138 146 15-168; an undetermined number of folios removed from the beginning of the manuscript; ruled in hard-point; prickings visible.|Layout: In 30-35 long lines.|Script: fol. 1r-108r written in caroline textualis formata by several hands; 108v-115r: written in caroline textualis media by several hands; fol. 1-107, headings and fold. 108-115, headings in rustic capitals. Fol. 1r and 8v, corrections by rubricator.|Decoration: fol. 20r and 28r: white vine stem initials decorated with yellow, green, and orange-red; f. 74r: white vine stem initial, uncolored; f. 90v: white vine stem initial decorated with brown and yellow; f. 14v: similar initial historiated with fantastic animal; f. 48v: initial historiated with dog, bird, and fantastic animal; f. 62r: orange-red initial decorated with green; f. 38r: red initial washed with yellow; f. 62r: red initial filled with green; f. 42r-103v: simple red initials; f. 108-115: initials in ink of text, marked in red.|Origin: Written in northern Italy in the middle of the 11th century, at Novalesa, as indicated by note on fol. 107v confirming perpetual wine supply to Saint Peter's at Novalesa. Fol. 12r, 17th century marginal note confirms presence at Novalesa. Fol. 1-107v was a separate book before being bound together with fol. 108-115; notes and restoration of obliterated portions date from the 18th century.|Given by the Abbot of Novalesa in the 18th century to Eugenio de Levis.|Formerly no. 8462 in the library of Sir Thomas Phillipps.|Sold March 1821, by Thomas Thorpe to Richard Heber.|Sold at auction in 1935 to Seymour de Ricci.

physical_description: Extent: 354 leaves : parchment, illustrations ; trimmed to 200 x 280 (211-225 x 148-150) mm
note: Manuscript codex.|Title from printed catalog.|Collation: Parchment, fol. 354; 1-158 168(-8) 17-308 316 32-368 376 38-438 4410.|Layout: fol. 1-48 and 128-354 in 40 lines in two columns, fol. 49-126 in 34 lines in two columns, fol. 127 irregularly ruled indicating that fol. 49-127 were written to fill in for folios lost from a preexisting manuscript; ruled in plummet; prickings visible on inner margins of fol. 49-127.|Script: Written by two scribes: fol. 1-48 and 128-354 in an early gothic textualis media, irregular word separation; fol. 49-127 in a later and more angular gothic textualis with increased fusion; guides to rubricator present in the earlier portion only.|1. Decoration: Miniatures in the style of Paris, 11 lines high, all on folios copied by the first hand: fol. 1r: the two kings and their wives (severely damaged); fol. 200r: Galahad with Lancelot behind him in armor on horseback riding through trees on a gold background; fol. 292r: Méléagant's sister in a boat approaches Lancelot, watching from a tower.|2. Decoration: Initials: alternating blue and red flourished initials throughout; those on fol. 49-127 frequently have penned representations of human faces and foliage.|Sewing holes visible around miniatures and initials, evidence of previously attached protective silk curtains.|Origin: Written in France, probably in Paris, ca. 1300; fol. 1-48 and 128-354 perhaps somewhat earlier.|Formerly in the library of Anne de Graville.|Former owner: Claude d'Urfé.|Purchased for 31 france, 10 sous by Tilliard for Pierre-Antonine Bolongaro-Crevenna.|Armorial bookplate of George Folliott.

physical_description: Extent: 1 roll (5 membranes) : parchment, illustrations ; 461 x 10 cm
note: Manuscript roll.|Title from printed catalog.|Layout: 167 long lines per sheet; ruled in brown pen.|Script: Written in cursica anglicana formata.|Decoration: Roll begins with a miniature of Christ on the Cross with the instruments of torture, accompanied by Mary and John the Evangelist. On the left, the mocking Jew; on the right, an unidentified seminude figure. Above, Christ or God the Father seated, accompanied by two standing figures with nimbi, the right one female, all deteriorated, upper right corner entirely missing. Rubic begins with magenta initials 6 lines high on a ground of blue and pink, accompanied by a piece of marginal floral decoration in the same colors and green. Text begins with a red and black initial 12 lines high, the interior decorated with patterned oak leaves. Minor red initials with flourishes in red and, after the first, in the ink of the text throughout. First letter of each line touched in red.|Origin: Written in England in a provincial scriptorium in about 1400.|Erased writing on the verso of first two sheets, text not identified.|Formerly in the library of Reginald Cholmondeley, Condover Hall, Shropshire.

physical_description: Extent: 158 leaves : parchment, illustrations ; 210 x 151 (110 x 70) mm
note: Ms. codex.|Title from printed catalog.|Collation: Parchment, fol. 158; 1-26 38 46(-6) 5-68 78(-8) 8-108 116(-1) 128 134 14-158 1610(-10); French post-medieval quire numbering in lower margin after the calendar.|Layout: Written in 15 long lines; ruled in violet ink.|Script: Written in gothic textualis formata.|Decoration: Fourteen half-page illuminations: fol. 13r (Four Evangelists); f. 27r (the Annunciation; fol. 37v (the Visitation); fol. 50r (the Nativity); fol. 56r (the Annunciation to the shepherds in the field); fol. 61r (the Adoration of the Magi); fol. 64v (the Presentation in the Temple); fol. 68 (the flight to Egypt); fol. 74r (the Coronation of the Virgin) fol. 80r (Crucifixion between the two thieves); fol. 86r (Pentecost); fol. 92r (King David in prayer inspired by Divine Light, harp beside him); fol. 109r (last rites over a corpse, and above, Michael saving a naked soul from the devil); fol. 153r (female owner portrait in prayer before the enthroned Virgin and Child, an angel playing a harp. Fol. 1 and each illuminated fol., a full border combining acanthus spray and rinceaux decoration with gold, blue, and magenta initials 2 lines high. All other fol., outer floral borders, and similar borders in the inner margin od the rectos in the presence of gold dentelle initials with white patterning on grounds of magenta and blue, 2 line high.|Origin: Written in France, probably in Rouen, ca. 1450.|Armorial bookplate of Comte François Potocki, Vilna.|Former owner: Henry Probasco.|Forms part of the Henry Probasco Collection at the Newberry Library.

note: Manuscript codex.|Title from printed catalog.|Collation: Parchment, fol. i + 243 (modern foliation 1-241); 110( -1) 2-510 612 710 8-118 12-1712 1810 19-258 268 (2-7 stubs only); catchwords.|Layout: Written in 38-40 long lines; frame ruled in pen; prickings visible.|Script: Written by at least two hands; fol. 1-78 in secretary media incorporating many anglicana traits; fol. 78-241 in a hybrida media incorporating many angelicana traits.|Decoration: Historiated initials with human faces, acorns, and oak leaves in red, fol. 1-78. Simple red initials and red paragraph marks throughout. Fol. 78r-204r, initial letter of each line of verse touched in red. Fol. 78r-235r, in prose sections, red used as punctuation.|Origin: Written in England; signed in red on fol. 207v by J. Clynton in 1480.|Former owner's inscription "Christoforus Lincolne Monachus" written in red in 15th century textualis, final letter historiated with face of a monk.|Owned by Thomas Sowthen; indenture between Sowthen and John Craven, dated 1574, written on outer margin of fol. 9r; fol. 241v: Thomas Sowthen dyed this last day of Aprill 1579. Mr. Thomas Sowthen did owne this boke / God gave him grace thereon to loke / and when he hath lokte to tak good hede / and marke the thinge that he doth rede / and I Isaac Frise will bere record / that it was Thomas Sowthens in the yere of our lord / 1 thousand fyve hundred seventie and seven / and so god send vs all the blis of heaven / Amen qoth Isaac Ffrise [his mark].|Former owner's signature of R. Alsen in an Elizabethan hand.|In the library of Lord Clifford of Ugbrooke Park, Chudleigh, Devonshire in the 20th century.

physical_description: Extent: 164 leaves : parchment, ill. ; 196 x 150 (93 x 70) mm
note: Manuscript codex.|Title from printed catalog.|Collation: Parchment, fol. 164 (fol. 159-164, paper 16th century); 112 28 36 4-108 122 12-138 148 152 16-218 226.|Layout: Written in 14 long lines; ruled in violet ink; calendar ruled for 17 lines.|Script: Written in gothic textualis rotunda media.|Decoration: Thirteen half-page miniatures accompanied by full acanthus spray borders decorated with many hybrid animal-men figures, exotic birds, and fantastic creatures: fol. 13r (Four evangelists in four panels); fol. 27r (the Annunciation); fol. 38v (the Visitation); fol. 55r (the Nativity); fol. 61 (the Annunciation to the shepherds in the field; in margin: naked bird-man or -woman with long beak penetrating its own rectum and an elephant with cloven hooves); fol. 65r (the Adoration of the Magi; in lower margin: a camel); fol. 69r: (the Presentation in the Temple; in margin: a male cripple courting a mermaid admiring herself in a mirror); fol. 73r (the Flight into Egypt; in the background: miracle of the cornfields and falling idol, the Holy family accompanied by a girl with a basket of doves); fol. 80r (Coronation of the Virgin; in margin: man-dog shooting at unicorn-bird); fol. 85r (King David in prayer with a harp present; in margin: man with unsheathed sword); fol. 104r (the Crucifixion; in margin: four roundels depicting, from upper righ to lower left: Christ in the Garden at Gethsemane, Christ bearing the cross, Christ before Pontius Pilate, and Christ nailed to the cross; in lower margin: a pelican in its piety, below the legend "Je meure pour vous"; fol. 108r (Pentecost; in lower margin: an anal sexual encounter between two beast-men); fol. 111r (a burial in a churchyard; outer margin: a Dominican friar).|Origin: Written in France, probably in Rouen in about 1470.|Former owner's annotations: fol. 1-2 in margins, nine unidentified proverbs in Latin, Greek, and French, dated twice 1595, all by one hand, possibly the same as that which added prayers on fol. 159-163.|Former owner's inscription: A. Schinkel Anno 1843.|Former owner: Henry Probasco.|Forms part of the Henry Probasco Collection at the Newberry Library.

physical_description: Extent: 142 leaves : parchment, ill. ; 222 x 158 (113 x 69) mm
note: Manuscript codex.|Title from printed catalog.|Collation: Parchment, fol. ii + 139 + i (foliated 1-142, flyleaves included in folation); 1-26 3-78 8 (entirely removed with loss of text) 9-108 118(-2) 12-138 144 15-188 194 208; catchwords.|Layout: Written in 16 long lines; ruled in violet.|Script: Written in textualis quadrata formata of uneven quality.|1. Decoration: Nine half-page illuminations accompanied by full gold and blue acanthus borders, decorated with flowers: fol. 23r (the Annunciation); fol. 40v (the Visitation); fol. 51v (the Nativity); fol. 55r (the Circumcision); fol. 58r (the Presentation in the temple); fol. 63r (the flight into Egypt); fol. 75r (Gnadenstuhl Trinity); fol. 78r (King David in prayer, a harp at his side, rays of light streaming to his eyes); fol. 98r (a funeral with casket borne by friars of at least two orders, three coats of arms with a black eagle on a gold field are visible on the wall); two miniatures probably removed as part of quire 8, a third removed after fol. 78.|2. Decoration: Four historiated initials accompanied by a similar bracket left marginal border: fol. 15r (the eagle); fol. 16r (the ox); fol. 17r (the lion); fol. 18r (the angel): symbols of the Four Evangelists with each holding a banderole with his name inscribed in French.|3. Decoration: fol. 128 and 131: full border decoration; fol. 137: bracket left border; blue initials filled with magenta alternating with magenta initials filled with blue, decorated with gold flora on gold ground 2-4 lines high throughout; gold dentelle initials with white patterning on grounds of blue and magenta, thoughout.|Origin: Written in western France, probably in Angers (from calendar and litany) in about 1450.|Former owner's inscription, modern (American?) pencil note on front flyleaf records 147 leaves, 11 large, 4 small miniatures, and 18 full borders; therefore, 8 folios and 2 illuminations had been removed from this codex prior to its foliation.|Formerly no. 20 in the collection of Henry Probasco.|Forms part of the Henry Probasco Collection at the Newberry Library.

physical_description: Extent: 209 leaves : parchment, ill. ; 162 x 112 (83 x 51) mm
note: Manuscript codex.|Title from printed catalog.|Collation: Parchment, fol. ii + 205 + ii (foliated 1-209, includes flyleaves); collation impracticable.|Layout: Written in 16 long line; ruled in violet ink.|Script: Written in gothic textualis quadrata media.|1. Decoration: Fifteen half-page illuminations by at least two artists in a style reminiscent of Maître François, accompanied by full blue and green acanthus spray borders with various flora including thistles, roses, and berries on grounds of different geometrical gold patterns: fol. 15r (angel encouraging John, eagle holding ink pot), fol. 31r (the Annunciation), fol. 57r (the Visitation), fol. 69r (the Nativity), fol. 75r (the Annunciation to the shepherds in the field, one shepherdess shearing sheep), fol. 80r (the Adoration of the Magi), fol. 85r (the Presentation in the Temple), fol. 90r (the flight into Egypt, by a different artist), fol. 97v (the Coronation of the Virgin), fol. 104r (King David in prayer, harp at his side, an angel with unsheathed sword above), fol. 124r (the Crucifixion between two thieves), fol. 131r (Pentecost), fol. 137r (the three living and the three dead), fol. 187r (the Virgin and Child enthroned between two angels, fol. 194r (the Trinity, Father and Son wearing one cloak, dove between them.|2. Decoration: Sixteen smaller illuminations 5 line high accompanied by an outer bracket border on a clear ground: fol. 17r (Luke), fol. 18v (Matthew), fol. 20v (Mark), fol. 197v (Michael), fol. 198 (John the Baptist), fol. 199 (John the Evangelist), fol. 199v (James), fol. 200r (Christopher), fol. 202r (Sebastian), fol. 203v (Anthony), fol. 204r (Lawrence), fol. 204v (Denis), fol. 205r (Catherine), fol. 206r (Margaret), fol. 206v (Barbara), fol. 207r (Geneviève).|3. Decoration: Two 5-line historiated initials also accompanied by an outer bracket border: fol. 21v (the letter O historiated with angels crowning the Virgin), fol. 26r (the letter O historiated with the Pietà). Gold dentelle initials with white patterning on grounds of blue and magenta throughout. Traced band borders on rectos and versos, facing folios, and on versos of facing folios.|Origin: Written in France in about 1460.|Belonged successively to Pieter de Hubert; Heer von Burgt (1627-1697); Anna Elizabeth van Panhuis; Elizabeth de Hochepied, purchased at her sale, The Hague, 1842, by A. D. Schinkel, his note of provenance in Dutch on verso of front flyleaf, dated 28 March 1842, his sale, The Hague, 21 November 1846, no. 32.|Laid in: four page note in Dutch, 19th century.|No. 22 from the collection of Henry Probasco.|Forms part of the Henry Probasco Collection at the Newberry Library.

note: Manuscript codex.|Title devised by cataloger.|Collation: Parchment, fol. i (paper) + 177 + i (paper); tightly bound, collection impracticable.|Layout: Written in 16 long lines; ruled in violet.|Script: Written in textualis formata.|Decoration 1: 14 full page illuminated miniatures (rectos left blank) with acanthus spray boarder with various flora including thistles, roses, and berries: fol. 23v (Crucifixion); fol. 28v (Pentecost); fol. 33v (Madonna and Child); fol. 48v (Annunciation); fol. 68v (Visitation); fol. 81v (Nativity); fol. 86v (Annunciation to the shepherds); fol. 91v (Adoration of the Magi); fol. 95v (Presentation at the temple); fol. 100v (Massacre of the Innocents); fol. 112v (Coronation of the Virgin); fol. 123v (Last Judgement); fol. 143v (Funeral).|Decoration 2: 6 small miniatures (7 lines): fol. 17r (John); fol. 18v (Luke ); fol. 20r (Matthew); fol. 21v (Mark); fol. 40r (pietà); fol. 44v (Madonna and Child).|Decoration 3: Throughout: 6-line initials in gold, 2-line gold initials with pink, blue, and white background; alternating blue, red, and gold initials with pen flourishes.|Origin: Probably produced in France between 1450 and 1475.|The first 4 leaves have been inserted from another manuscript; They consist of 4 full-page miniatures (with blanks): fol. 1v: St. George killing the dragon (dragon in cave, princess in background); fol. 2r: John the Baptist (wearing hair-shirt; holding agnus dei on book holding cross banner); fol. 3v: Saint Anthony the Great (with pig, book, and staff with bell); fol. 4r: Saint Francis (holding cross and book, stigmata and tear in brown habit showing wound).|Inscription on fol. 1r: Tullius Franciscus A.D. MCCCXXXIII.|Inscription on fol. 4r: Memento mey.

subject_as_recorded: Ballads, Italian--Italy--Tuscany--Early works to 1800|Love songs--Italy--Tuscany--Early works to 1800|Part songs, Italian--Early works to 1800|Music--Manuscripts|Manuscripts, Italian--Italy--Tuscany
physical_description: Extent: 1 item : parchment ; 18 cm.
note: Four-leaf fragment from a 15th-century song book, probably Tuscan in origin, containing music for five ballads for two and three tenor and countertenor voices, with accompanying text in Italian.|Six five-line staves in red with square notation in black; text in black.|Folds and stitching holes in outer margins suggest that the pages were used to reinforce another binding.|For a detailed description of this manuscript, see: Paolo Tenorista in a new fragment of the Italian Ars Nova ; a facsimile edition of an early fifteenth-century manuscript in the library of Professor Edward E. Lowinsky, Berkeley, California, with an introduction by Nino Pirrotta. Palm Springs : Ernest E. Gottlieb, 1961.|Accompanied by photographs of the manuscript, two autograph letters signed from Nino Pirrotta to Professor Lowinsky, and other materials in typescript form dealing with the manuscript.

holding_institution_shelfmark: VAULT Case MS oversize M2147 XV .M1
subject_as_recorded: Music--Manuscripts
physical_description: Extent: 1 ms. score ([153] leaves) ; 47 cm
note: Manuscript on vellum, produced in Germany in the 14th or 15th century.|Choir-book format, with music (plain-chant notation) on a five-line staff written in Nagelschrift. Decorated initials in black, red, and blue.|The first 11 leaves (foliated ij-xij) have been inserted, probably contemporaneously, from another ms. seemingly prepared at the same scriptorium as that of the main text. These inserted leaves have 9 staffs per page, whereas the main text has 10. Also these leaves, being shorter, have been lengthened by the addition of vellum strips at the bottom.|The main text (starting on leaf [12]) is foliated ix-clxxxii, but there are many gaps in the foliation, and the folios are bound out of order. For details, see sheet accompanying the volume.|The last leaf is an extraneous insertion.|Imperfect: piece cut from folio ci, with slight loss of text; a few leaves are slashed in the margins.

physical_description: Extent: 22] leaves, bound : parchment, color illustrations ; 34 cm (fol.)
note: Text in a neat gothic hand in brown ink, lightly ruled in lead, and arranged in two columns; catchwords at bottom of last leaf of first quire (leaf [10]v), and second quire (leaf [22]v); center margins at beginning and end of main text decorated with leaves and dots in lavender, blue, teal, ocher, red, green, and gilt; remaining center margins throughout text are red and blue, with red and blue penwork flourishes; alternating capitals in red and blue, with contrasting penwork in blue and red; beginning of each sentence marked in red; chapter numbers and headlines in red and blue; pricking holes visible along outer edges of leaves.|Ms. marginalia in a miniscule hand contain guide numbers for the rubricator, and omission notes and corrections by scribe.|Illuminated capitals at beginning of prologue and end of text, in red, lavender, dark blue, light blue, and white on gilt background; larger illuminated capital "E" at beginning of text (leaf 1v) adorned with portraits of the sleeping Christ, and the Four Evangelists in lavender, blue, teal, orange, red, and green on gilt background.|Bookplate of Carl Hermann Grabauer.

note: Manuscript codex.|Title from first line of text.|At head of text: "Y[e]h[s]us Maria."|Layout: Written in 23-27 long lines.|Script: Written in a "bastarda" hand, with few abbreviations.|Decoration: Prologue and chapter titles in red; beginning letter of each sentence touched in gold; one 5-line and 46 2-line initials in red, decorated with lines and dots in gold, lavender, and brown gouache, and accompanied by marginal columns and catchword decorations of flowers, leaves, vines, and penwork in similar colors, some containing human faces, monsters, grotesques, animals, and flowers.|Origin: Devotional text by Dominican father, Domenico Cavalca, probably written in Tuscany during the second quarter of the 15th century.|Text is left incomplete at end, due to missing quire, the absence of which was probably intended to be disguised by a fictitious colophon added later in a different red ink: "Mateo Giraldi senese scrise in Sena l'anno del Signore G.C. physical_description: Extent: 234] leaves, bound : parchment ; 32 cm.
note: Explicit on recto of leaf [42]--"Explicit ysto[r]ia pa[ssio]nis d[omi]ni nostri i[es]hu [christ]i extracta de passione q[ui] sc[ri]psit Mag[iste]r Arma[n]dus doctor sacri palatij"--and similar chapter heading on verso of leaf [35] suggest that a section of the present text may have been written by Armand de Belvézer, a Franciscan friar who served as lecturer for Pope John XXII, and authored three books: two books of "collationes" or sermons, both printed in Paris in 1519, and "Declaratio dictionum ac dictorum difficilium in Theologia ac philosophia", printed in Basel in 1491.|Text in two rounded gothic bookhands in brown ink, arranged in two columns of 44 lines per page; alternating red and blue capitals, with contrasting blue, purple, or red penwork tracery; alternating red and blue paragraph strokes; headings in red; catchwords; bounding lines lightly ruled in brown; some natural parchment flaws, with text written around them.|Marginal captions in bookhand; marginal corrections and instructions to rubricator in a different smaller hand.|Tears in vellum leaves have been repaired with stitching.|Leaves arranged in 18 quires of 12 leaves; first quire has 5 leaves, and third has 13 leaves.|Front and back pastedowns are vellum leaves of early antiphonals, with square notation in brown arranged on red 5-lined staves, with Latin words in large rounded lowercase roman letters.

physical_description: Extent: 89] leaves, bound : parchment ; 13 cm
note: Text in two scribal hands in brown ink (leaves 1-23, and 23-86 of original foliation); in a single column, 28-32 lines per page; initials in red at the beginning of the life of each saint; capitals throughout text touched in red; Arabic foliation and month in red at top of each leaf.|Includes table of contents with folio and chapter numbers in both arabic and roman numerals for life of each saint through St. Bartholomew on leaf 54 of original foliation.|Reader's aids present in ms.--table of contents, foliation and chapter numbers, headlines identifying months of year--reflect desire of mendicant writers to make material on lives of the saints more accessible to lay population.|Text of ms. mistakenly identified as Jacobus de Voragine's "Legenda aurea", indicated by "Voragine" written on second flyleaf in an early 19th-century hand; by typewritten notice "Legenda aurea" affixed to inside of front board; and by earlier inscription "Jacobus Reverendo Padre Salutem" and "Legendarius" on first flyleaf.|Contemporary brown leather over (probably) original wood boards, with bevelled edges.|Published as Liber epilogorum in gesta sanctorum / Bartolomeo da Trento ; edizione critica a cura di Emore Paoli. Tavarnuzze (Firenze) : SISMEL edizioni del Galluzzo, 2001.

physical_description: Extent: 66] leaves, bound (last leaf blank) : parchment ; 19 cm.
note: Caption title.|Terminal date based on note in Latin, dated June 8, 1470 at the chateau d'Amboise, by Jean Bouchart de la Vaucelle, bishop of Avranches between 1453 and 1484, in which he dedicated the ms. to Louis XI, for whom he served as adviser and confessor; cf. verso of leaf [66].|Caption title in red; text in brown ink; 24 lines per page in an italic hand; large illuminated initial "S" in burgundy and white on gold background, overlaid with drawing of French royal arms in blue and gold; illuminated ornamental border in burgundy, blue, and gold on three sides of text block; pictorial borders on four sides in green, blue, brown, and gold, containing human and animal figures, large fronds, leaves, flowers, and a second drawing of the French royal arms in blue and gold supported by two kneeling figures; smaller alternating illuminated capitals in burgundy and blue on contrasting backgrounds throughout text.|Latin and English text published as Epistola ad Mahomatem II = Epistle to Mohammed II / Aeneas Silvius Piccolomini ; edited with a translation, and notes by Albert R. Baca. New York : Peter Lang, c1990.|Newer tan calf binding, with double blind-ruled borders on upper and lower boards; blind-stamped lozenge ornaments in spine compartments; dark blue gold-stamped spine label with title "Pii II Mahumeti epistola"; marbled endpapers.|Small ownership labels on front pastedown, and front endpaper, with initials "A.G.T." and "C.B." respectively.|Notes in a later hand second front endpaper, describing ms.; additional notes in the same hand on back endpaper, providing transcription of Boucart's note of 1470 on verso of last vellum leaf.

title_as_recorded: Les lignées des roys de France
subject_as_recorded: Nobility--France--Genealogy|Church buildings--France--History|Illumination of books and manuscripts, French|Manuscripts, French--France|France--Kings and rulers--Genealogy|France--Kings and rulers--Biography|France--History--Sources
physical_description: Extent: 1 roll (9 leaves) : parchment, col. ill. ; 687 x 33 cm
note: Date suggested by dates of reign of Louis XI (1461-1483), last king included in original ms.; ninth sheet was apparently added later to include Charles VIII and Louis XII, who reigned from 1483-1498 and 1498-1515, respectively.|Caption title: "Cy senssuivent les lignees des roys de France, et co[m]ment les generations sont descendues lune de lautre; et co[m]ment elles sont faillies; et si parle en brief de leurs faiz et en quel temps ilz ont regne et combien et ou ilz gisent et quelx enfans ilz ont eu; et en quel temps fut la cite de Lutesse fomentee et co[m]ment elle fut no[m]mee Paris; et co[m]ment le royaume de gaule fut no[m]mé France; et si pouez veoire par figures aucunes notables eglises que les roys qui ont este en France ont fondees [...?] en son temps."|Composed of nine sheets of vellum glued together to form a continuous long roll; text in a bâtard hand in red and brown; large illuminated letter "A" at head of text in red and gold on blue background; smaller alternating red and blue illuminated initials throughout; left and right margins decorated with wide vertical bands of red and green; center margin separating columns of text decorated with similar vertical bands of red, buff, and brown; illustrations of churches in brown and gray, within circular borders of green and tan; some medallions in red, containing names in red; background illustrations throughout of flowers, leaves, clovers, and wild strawberries in red, green, blue, white, and buff.|Added title on verso of ms., in black ink in a later hand: "Lignees des rois de France depuis Pharamond jusque à Louis XI."|Original ms., in color (first 8 sheets), ends with Louis XI; ninth sheet added to roll to include later kings, Charles VIII and Louis XII, whose entries are not colored or illuminated, and whose descriptions appear in a different hand.|In rust brown cloth-covered clamshell box, resting in customized "trough", and secured with cloth tie.

note: Date and title from inscription on recto of leaf [149]: "Fine[m] accepit hoc manuale anno d[omi]ni 1519..."|Strong emphasis throughout on worship of the Virgin suggests that perhaps this prayer-book was used by a woman, perhaps a member of a religious order; special reference to St. Benedict on recto of leaf [149] suggests that perhaps user was a Benedictine nun [?].|Text in at least three different gothic hands in brown and black ink on vellum, lightly ruled in graphite; capitals and captions in red; sentence initials touched in red; large ornamental two-tone capitals in red, blue, and green; at head of text is a large zoomorphic letter "O"--a serpent swallowing its own tail--in pink, rose, and gold.|Illustrated with a drawing of a bleeding red heart pierced by two green arrows and a long, two-handled saw, surmounted by an illuminated gold crown (verso of leaf [149]); preceding the Office of the Dead is a drawing of a skull (verso of leaf [125]).|Single lines of chant music arranged on black 4-line staves, with square notation in black; staves on verso of leaves [117] and [118] lacking notes.|A few miscellaneous marginal annotations; erasure of a line of text on verso of leaf [74].|Forms part of the Howard Mayer Brown Collection at the Newberry Library.

note: Four lines of music per page; music arranged on red four-line staves, with square notation in dark brown; Latin words in a rounded gothic bookhand; captions and numbers in red; large initials in red with violet calligraphic penwork, or in black with yellow penwork, sometimes incorporating grotesques; simple red initials on last [7] p., which appear to have been added later in a different hand; catchwords within decorated frames in red and black.|Modern black calf, neatly merged with portions of the original blind-stamped covers, with multiple rolled borders, and small blind-stamped leaf motifs in center panel.|Front flyleaf is a vellum leaf from an earlier German music manuscript, with music arranged on 4-line staves, and square notation and Latin words in brown.|Forms part of the Howard Mayer Brown Collection at the Newberry Library.

subject_as_recorded: Aesop's fables--Translations into Latin|Tobias (Biblical figure)--Poetry--Early works to 1800|Tobias (Biblical figure)|Fables, Greek--Translations into Latin--Early works to 1800|Latin poetry|Manuscripts, Latin (Medieval and modern)|Fables, Greek|Latin poetry|Manuscripts, Latin (Medieval and modern)
physical_description: Extent: 51] leaves : parchment ; 190 x 140 mm
note: Manuscript codex.|Poetry.|Collation: Parchment, 51; 110 28 310 4-58 67.|Layout: Written in 26 long lines; text and bounding lines lightly ruled in brown; prickings visible along fore-edge of each leaf.|Script: Humanistic hand in brown ink.|Decoration: Large capitals, paragraph marks, and titles in red vermilion; some red capitals pen-flourished in brown; smaller initials of each line touched in yellow ochre; catchwords in brown and ochre, within decorative frames.|Origin: Probably transcribed around 1500. A version of Aesop's fables in Latin verse, followed by Matthew de Vendôme's poem on the Biblical patriarch, Tobias. This version of Aesop's fables, consisting of two books containing 55 fables, is generally thought to have been written by Matthew l'Anglais, probably around 1175. Tobias, by the 12th century Latin poet, Matthew de Vendôme, is based on the account by St. Jerome, and was printed in many eds., including those of 1479, 1505, 1520, and 1540.|Tipped in at leaf [18]: small slip of blue paper, with manuscript note in a later hand, entitled "Poème de Tobie, latin vers héxamètre."

physical_description: Extent: 73] leaves, bound ; 21 cm.
note: Scribe's name and date of production from colophon (verso of leaf [72]): "Iste liber est ad usum mei fratris Laurentii de pisis ordinis minorum quem propria manu scripxi et uocatur speculum ecclesie anno ab incarnatione domini M⁰.CCCC⁰.LXXI. die. 9. agusti amen."|Orthographic conventions, such as use of "x" for "s" in middle of word, and substitution of "ch" for "c", suggest Tuscany, possibly Pisa, as place of production.|Text in a clear Italian semi-gothic hand in brown ink by a single scribe; text and bounding lines lightly ruled in lead; section headings and paragraph marks in red; initials of some sentences touched in red; four illuminated gilt capitals on varying backgrounds of red, blue, green, and fuschia; two smaller gilt capitals; 17 small initials--most are red and blue, but four are gilt--cut out of other mss. and pasted into this ms; some blank spaces with guide letters; catchwords.|Contemporary limp vellum binding, reinforced with strips of vellum ms. waste, the text of which is visible in brown and red; heavy thick brown leather sewing thongs; remnants of two pairs of leather ties; ms. titles on front cover and spine; cover title "Speculu[m] eccl[es]ie."|Ownership inscription on verso of leaf [2]: "Petri Maphei f[iliorum]q]ue] Hob: Hier[oni]mi et Amicorum."|Excerpt on recto of leaf [2]: "Augustinus super Psalmum XXI"; and extensive ms. marginal notes in same hand as ex-libris, presumably the hand of Maffei himself.|In phase box.|For additional information, consult the Special Collections Info File.
