physical_description: Extent: 93] leaves, bound : parchment ; 17 cm.
note: Place of production suggested by script, penwork, and preparation of parchment.|Range of possible dates suggested by inclusion of "Sanctificatio Marie", the name of which was changed after 1341; and by absence of sermons in the Sanctoral for either Mary Magdalene or Hugh of Lincoln, both of which were added to the office after 1368. Cf. J. Mourlier and R. du Moustier, "Le calendrier Cartusien," Etudes Grégoriennes 2 (1957): 151-61.|Text written by two scribes in a very neat Italianate hand, perhaps Bolognese script, in brown ink, on fine parchment of Italian preparation; 31 lines per page; catchwords in ornamental cartouches and bounding lines in brown; captions, marginal references and foliation of leaves i-lii in red; paragraph marks in red and blue; beginnings of sentences touched in red; large red and blue initial, with red and yellow penwork infill and surround, and pen flourishing along margins in yellow, red, and violet; smaller initials alternating in red and blue, with violet and red pen flourishing, respectively; all edges gilt.|Incipit (part 1): "Incipit omeliae s[an]c[t]o[rum]; In s[an]c[t]o Andrea. S[er]mo b[eat]i Aug[ustin]i ep[iscop]i"; incipit (part 2): "Incipiu[n]t ep[isto]le b[ea]ti Pauli ap[osto]li. Lege[n]de ta[m] do[meni]cis dieb[us] q[uam] f[est]i[v]alib[us] us[que] ad lxx. Que legi i[n]cipiu[n]t p[ri]ma die post circu[m]cisione"; incipit (part 3): "Incipit officiu[m] defunctor[um]"; incipit (part 4): "Incipiu[n]t [con]stituto[n]es diuini officii [secundum] Ordine[m] Cart[usem]".

physical_description: Extent: 150] leaves, bound : parchment, col. ill. ; 25 cm.
note: Place of production suggested by the inclusion of local Rhenish saints, as well as special veneration of saints specific to Mainz, such as Saint Martin, bishop of Mainz--depicted in the only historiated initial in the ms.--and Saint Bilhildis. Decorated initials executed in a style found in books written and printed in Mainz.|Possible date suggested by striking similarity of script and large initials, especially the scrolled infill and the grotesques, with the Psalter and Missal printed by Gutenberg, Fust, and Schoeffer, who at that time were undertaking a project to provide books for the reform of the liturgy of the Bursfeld Congregation. The Collectarium ms. might have been a model for a similar project, planned but never executed.|Original portion of text in dark brown ink in a large formal gothic liturgical hand; 17 lines per page; alternating red and blue 2-line initials throughout, some with pen flourishes, and one 3-line blue initial "D" pen-flourished in red; chapter titles, section headings, and headlines in red; capitals touched in red.|Includes five 8-line or 5-line historiated and/or decorated initials, divided into red and blue sections, and all but one enclosing figures of dragons, calves [?] and griffins with goat feet, and human figures, male and female, also with goat feet; one letter contains two logs sprouting trefoils, another a Germanic helm with horns and long acanthus scrolls; all decorated with some type of red or brown penwork infill and surround flourishes with grotesque heads; smaller historiated initial on verso of leaf [113] contains cameo portrait of St. Martin as bishop of Mainz.|Leaves have been assembled and changed at different times; make-up of certain quires has shifted; leaves [1]-[4], [15]-[16], [123]-[133], and [145]-[150] added during the early 17th century, as evidenced by scribal addition "Anno 1607 ... renovavit D.P.P.C.A." on recto of leaf [145]; single partial leaves tipped in after leaves [47], [79], and [92]; and 4 small leaves tipped in after leaf [133]; many ms. additions and notes made during Middle Ages and later.|In a modern full pale brown morocco clamshell box by Sangorski & Sutcliffe of London.|Acquired by Maggs Bros. at Sotheby's (London) auction of June 18, 1962, lot 134.|Ownership inscription in pencil on back pastedown: M. Lansburgh, Santa Barbara.|Forms part of the Howard Mayer Brown Collection at the Newberry Library.|For additional information, consult the Special Collections Info File.

physical_description: Extent: 45] leaves, bound : parchment and paper, music ; 13 cm.
note: Possible date suggested by textual references.|Title in Phillipps catalog: "Psalmi vespertini cum precibus et calendario".|Text in a gothic bookhand in black and red; 21 lines per page; capitals in red and blue; some larger red and blue initials with purple pen-flourishing; left and right margins double-ruled in red.|Eighteenth-century Latin text set to music, arranged on 4-line staves in brown or red, with square notation in brown.|Engraved illustration of the Virgin and Child within a circle of flames, dated 1592, on front pastedown.|One of 136 mss. which, at the time of the French Revolution, came through private hands into the possession of Cologne book dealers J.M. Heberle, and Heinrich Lempertz, who sold them in 1821 to Marburg theologian Leander van Ess. Cf. Barbaram quotidie," memorials of Saints Joseph, Peter and Paul, and Francis, in Latin, and text of a papal bull in German from 1685.|Formerly no. 544 in the library of Sir Thomas Phillipps.|Ex-libris inkstamp of Sir Thomas Phillipps of Middlehill, who acquired the ms. from van Ess in 1824; library number 544 on front endpaper; above is a ms. note "Phillipps Ms. 544"; verso of leaf [40] contains inkstamp of the Southport Libraries.|For additional information, consult the Special Collections Info File.

physical_description: Extent: 130] leaves, bound : parchment, col. ill., coats of arms ; 22 cm.
note: Title from verso of leaf [21].|Text in gothic hand in brown ink; 17 lines per page; margins and lines of text lightly ruled in red; calendar in brown and red ink; canonical hours, captions, and instructions of main text highlighted in red; large illuminated initials and line fillers in rose, blue, and gilt, with white penwork infill; ; elaborate illuminated borders containing flowers, vines, and acanthus leaves, birds, such as owls, swans, peacocks, storks, and albatrosses, strawberries, poppies, trees, gilt crowns, and a hunter--with bow, arrow, and hound--pursuing a stag.|Includes ten illuminated miniatures of scenes from the life of Christ in blue, green, orange, gray, brown, white, and gilt; paintings, within square blue and gilt borders, curved on top, depict the Virgin and the saints; Annunciation; visitation of the Virgin with St. Elizabeth; Nativity; annunciation of the birth of Jesus to the shepherds; Presentation in the temple; Massacre of the innocents; Flight into Egypt; Last Judgment; and Office of the Dead being sung by priests and monks.|Top of leaf [29] replaced with a different piece of vellum, on which text has been rewritten, more closely-spaced, and in darker ink; illuminated border has been interrupted as well, suggesting the correction of a mid-page error or omission.|Prickings visible along outer margins of leaves.|Illuminated arms of former owners, a comte du Lude and his wife, a member of the house of Boifeuillet, on leaves [47v] and [69v]; arms of the count alone on leaves [58v], [62v], [74r], and [94v].|Notations by another owner, in a later hand, on calendar leaves [3r], [5r], and [11v], indicating special occurrences such as a particular Easter followed by an earthquake, the taking of vows, and the death of a father, for the years 1578, 1580, 1586.|Imperfect: calendar leaves for January wanting.|Binding signed "Arnold a Lille 1866" on front pastedown.|Bookplates: Jay Gould and Helen Gould Shepard.

note: Title from rubricated heading on first leaf of text (leaf [2]). Formerly incorrectly transcribed as: In festo corpis xpi [christi] ad us[um] d[om]i[n]i.|Date suggested by style of handwriting and capital flourishes, and by calendar arrangement: i.e., ms. includes feasts of St. Dionysius and the Conception of the Virgin as single celebrations, first celebrated as such in 1481 and 1491, respectively; but lacks the observance of the feast of St. Servatius as a single celebration, a practice which dates from 1498, thus suggesting possible range of dates between 1481 and 1498. Cf. For additional information, consult the Special Collections Info File.|First line of text (leaf [2]): "Sacerdos in eternu[m] xps [christus] d[omin]us s[e]c[un]d[u]m ordine[m] melchisedechi panem [et] uinam obtulit."|First line of calendar (leaf [9]): "Marci[us] h[abet] dies xxxi luna xxx."|Calendar in red and black, with large red and blue capitals at head of each page, most with interlacing pen flourishes in blue; following calendar is a table for computing the date of Easter each year, in red and black, with folded fore-edge; and two diagrams for assigning Dominical Letters and Golden Numbers, also in red and black.|Text in a single hand, in a southwestern German "bastarda" script in black ink; leaves lightly ruled in brown; large red and blue capitals, some pen-flourished, or decorated with flowers, leaves, plumes, or trailing branches; smaller red and blue initials throughout text; captions and section numbers in red.|Upper margin of recto of leaf [103] contains a small pen-and-ink drawing in red, blue and brown ink, of two birds atop a pair of acanthus leaves, pecking a berry.|Last three leaves are blank; inscription on last leaf: "Logos Xhrist[us]."|Calendar leaf for January/February wanting.|Portions of leaves [17], [18], [50], [52], [108]-[111] have been slashed or cut out.

physical_description: Extent: 126] leaves, bound : parchment, color coat of arms ; 14 cm
note: Text in red and brown or black ink, on vellum leaves, with margins lightly ruled in brown ink; captions for each section or prayer, first lines, and line spacers in red; sentences in the Psalms highlighted with red capitals; capitals embellished with elaborate calligraphic flourishes in black; Werner's "new style" of calligraphy is evident, especially in the red Moorish-style ornament ("Maureskenornament") on bottom of leaf [4].|Leaves comprising the section of Psalms signed with imitation signatures: A-X4 Y2.|Presentation, dated 1576, fourteen years after prayer-book was produced, by Johann Schollen to his friend Christoff Kobolt on recto of leaf [2], within a rectangular cartouche, illuminated in red, blue, yellow, and gold, and embellished with a lion's head, the face of the sun, and garlands.|Illuminated frontispiece painting of [Kobolt's?] coat of arms--a rampant lion holding a branch of holly? leaves--in blue, rose, green, black, brown, and gold.|For additional information on Werner, cf. Schön schreiben eine Kunst: Johann Neudörffer und die Kalligraphie des Barock / Werner Doede. München: Prestel, c1988, p. 49. For citations to other works by Werner, cf. D.E. Smith, Rara arithmetica (4th ed.), no. 300; and W. Doede, Bibliographie deutscher Schreibmeisterbücher von Neudörffer bis 1800 (Hamburg, 1958), no. 19.

physical_description: Extent: 91] leaves, bound ; 15 x 22 cm.
note: Madrigals bear original ink numbering in three separate series; music arranged on five-line staves in brown ink, in round notation; Italian words below music.|Of the [91] leaves, [53] leaves contain music; [38] leaves contain blank staves only.|Part book was originally part of a larger complex of manuscripts devoted to the madrigal repertory; companion tenor part to the alto, and four additional partbooks from a second set of books of similar date, copied by the same scribe, now in the Biblioteca Comunale of Civitanova Marche, a small town on the Adriatic coast. For the earliest announcement of the existence of these mss., and a brief description of them, cf. I. Fenlon & J. Haar, "Fonti e cronologia dei madrigali di Costanzo Festa," Rivista italiana di musicologia 13 (1978): 212-242 (esp. p. 228); and Census-catalogue of manuscript sources of polyphonic music, 1440-1550, v. 4, p. 331, 332.

physical_description: Extent: 83] leaves, bound : parchment ; 24 cm. (4to)
note: Title from incipit.|Probable range of dates based on early rigid page format used between 1130 and 1150, which resulted in gaps between glosses, creating the impression of being incomplete. By about 1170, a more flexible layout had been adopted, in which the format was adjusted from page to page according to the relative length of text to gloss, thus eliminating gaps and blank areas.|Biblical text, written in a large proto-gothic bookhand in brown ink on vellum leaves lightly ruled in gray, and arranged in a narrow central column of 23 lines per page; accompanying marginal gloss in a smaller hand of up to 50 lines per page, also in brown ink; capitals touched in red; headlines, chapter numbers, and explicit in red; prickings visible along outer margins.|Later ms. additions and corrections in black ink indicate that the ms. was in use up to the sixteenth century.|Signatures: [1]8 (-[1]3) [2]-[10]8 [11]4; lacking a single leaf after leaf [2]; quire numbers preserved on final versos of gatherings [7] and [10].|Sixteenth-century inscriptions on verso of leaf [76]: "Nicolas de Feustden [?] a l'abbae monsieur St. Eloi le Noion", presumably a reference to a monk of the Benedictine abbey of St. Eloi in Noyon; and verso of leaf [42]: "Ce present livre appartient a jaque lemaire."|Illustrated bookplate of George Horace Johnstone ("G.H.J.") and his wife, Alison Johnstone ("A.J."), dated 1933; center medallion is an engraving of the Hawkins/Johnstone estate in Cornwall, Trewithan [Trewithen].|Ownership inscription in pencil on front endpaper of the library at Bignor Park, the Sussex estate once owned by George Horace Johnstone's great-great uncle, John Hawkins (fl. 1829-1839), and purchased by Lord Mersey in 1926. It was John Hawkins who oversaw the planting of the holm-oaks in the Great Park at Trewithen from acorns collected at Bignor Park.

note: Title from opening rubric.|Title in Saenger catalog: Enarrationes in Psalmos (Part I).|Manuscript codex.|Collation: Parchment, fol. 160 + i (modern foliation 1-161) ; 1-208 ; catchwords partially trimmed.|Layout: fol. 1r-159v, ruled in hard point with double boundary lines, two horizontal lines above and below extending into margin; fol. 160r-160v, rules in ink, 14th century; prickings visible in some outer and lower margins; quire 9 pricked in inner margins.|Script: Written in caroline textualis formata of the Norman variety; fol. 160, in gothic textualis of 14th century, written with an unusual gothic ampersand, minimal fusion, and long terminal s to complement the already existing codex.|Decoration: Plain initials in blue, green, or orange-red up to 13 lines high, throughout.|Origin: Main codex (fol. 1r-160v) written in England in the second third of the 12th century, certainly before approximately 1170 when dry point ruling disappeared; fol. 160 written in the 14th century at Cistercian Monastery of Ford, to whose library the codex then belonged.|Former owner's inscription of same 15th century hand responsible for marginalia: Edward Schepherde promysyd to pay xvs furtnyght after seynt James day nex ensuing. Item, a bargayn mayd for v pense a wek on seynt Mary Maudelyns eve with Elizabeth Whawen. Of [th]is Sheper[de] is recuyed vi s. viiid parte of [th]is xvs above wretyn. On sent Johanne a baptist day Rychard Gye have recuyd iii score of rede shevys."|Former owner's signature, 16th century: W. Smethwik.|Former owner's inscription: Sept. 1, 1748 by the hands of Mr. Denisham of Tiverton. Mr. Richards [of] Exeter returned this manuscript to the Abbey of Ford [signed] Francis Gwyn.|Former owner's inscriptions, fol. 73, "Richarde Cabel"; fol. 72, "Ry Cabil"; inscription in cipher by Cabel on fol. 125.|Typed dealer description, suggesting that this codex may have been written at St. Alban's, pasted to front endpaper.

physical_description: Extent: 2], 20, [1] leaves, bound : parchment and paper ; 32 cm.
note: In different hands in different notarial scripts, some formal, some cursive.|First two and last leaves are former pastedowns; all three are parchment, containing ms. music from a gradual from ca. 1200; square notation in dark brown on four- and five-line staves, lightly ruled in brown; red and blue capitals, with some light red pen flourishing; verso of leaf [1] contains a large painted capital "U" in the "Channel style", probably French from ca. 1200, in which the interior of the letter in brown and green, is filled with intertwined serpents and vines in orange and green; recto of leaf [2] contains table of contents with title "Repertoriu[m]"; drawing on recto of last leaf of a silver cross, made for the Dominicans by one of their members, Federico Reccamator[e], with his description, in Italian, probably from ca. 1577.|For additional background, cf. Alle origini del notariato italiano / Mario Amelotti and Giorgio Costamagna. Roma : Consiglio nazionale del notariato, 1975.

note: Manuscript codex.|Title from printed catalog.|Collation: Parchment (southern preparation), fol. ii + 79 + ii (modern foliation 1-44, five unfoliated leaves, 45-74) ; 1-710 810 (-10).|Layout: Text 1 written in 29 long lines with writing on the first ruled line, remainder in 27 long lines beginning on second ruled line; ruled in hard point with double boundary lines; prickings in outer margins.|Script: Written in humanistic textualis media characterized by gothic proportions and occasional gothic traits in very black ink; one 15th-century corrector or reader had added index notes, punctuation, and prosodiae as well as manicules; fol. 1, headings in red and red marginal index notes; index notes, mostly proper names, added by several hands in the remainder of manuscript.|Decoration: Spaces for initials left blank, beginning in text 3, guide letters present.|Origin: Written in northern Italy, certainly after 1440, the date of the composition of text 3.|Former owner's inscription on front flyleaf in Hebrew, possibly a pawn note.|On rear pastedown in pencil "39662".

physical_description: Extent: 236 leaves : paper ; trimmed to 280 x 200 (205 x 150) mm
note: Manuscript codex.|Title from printed catalog.|Collation: Paper, fol. 236 ; fol. 1-108v (an arbre water mark not in Briquet), fol. 109-235 (a raisin watermark, cf. Briquet 12993 and a croix à deux travers, ct. Briquet 5762) [these two sections were probably separate volumes as indicated by a colophon on fol. 108r and ownership note on fol. 109r] ; fol. 1-108, collation impracticable, but four pages removed after fol. 35 with loss of text; fol. 109-236, 1-1012 1112 (-9-12 with loss of text); fol. 109-236, catchwords in lower right margin, sometimes underlined in red.|Layout: Written 2 columns in 42-51 lines; frame-ruled in pencil, sometimes very lightly; guides for chapter headings in outer margin, underlined in red; guides for chapter roman numerals throughout.|Script: Written in gothic cursiva media in two hands (the break falling after fol. 108); fol. 109-236 in darker ink; headings of the books in red in script of text, chapter numbers in red roman numerals|Decoration: fol. 1-108, running headlines in upper margin in gothic capitals in red and black, a flourish in black or red on either side; fol. 109-236, running headings in larger gothic cursiva, underlined in red with a flourish in black ink on either side; alternating red and blue initials; guides for initials in ink of scribe present.|Origin: fol. 1r-180v written by Gerard de Scurhoven in 1433, and the entire book willed by him to brothers of the third order of Saint Francis in Zepperen in 1456, colophon on fol. 108r, "Scriptus est hic liber per manus Gerardi de Scurhoven presbiteri leodiensis diocesis pro tunc capellani cure beghinarum opidi Sancti Trudonis et finitus anno domini millesimo quadringentesimo tricesimo tercio mensis marcii die secunda, orate pro eo"; Added in another hand, "Presertim pro animo eius cui domum fratrum 3ii [ordinis] in Zeppren [?] contulit hunc librum. Obiit eius perfatus dominus Gerardus anno xiiiic lvio mensis iulii." Fol. 109r, lower margin, "Liber fratrum tertii ordinis in Zepperen legatus anno domini xiiiic lxio mensis iulii dei Xm."

E questo uide prouare in la rochea de Soma Cologna in Garfagniana piu e piu uolte. 1470 a di primo de nouembre. The second dated 1560 in a gloss is reproduced and analyzed in J.M. Arreola's Códices y documentos en mexicano (in M. Gamio's La Poblacion del valle de Teotithuacán, p. 553-8). The American Museum and Newberry copies are reproduced in S. Hagar's Celestial plan of Teotihuacán and the Handbook of Middle American Indians. All three mss. are discussed and reproduced in G. Kubler's Mazapan maps of Teotihuacán in 1560.|Dimensions estimated for the original size of the sheet of amatl paper on which the map was drawn; now separated into 6 fragments.|Colored inks (black, yellow, green, red, brown, blue) on amatl paper.|Relief shown pictorially.|Includes two layers of backing removed from map. Ayer Manuscript Map Collection and the Edward E. Ayer Manuscript Collection (Newberry Library).|Notes on the W.W. Blake backing identify location of stone box in which the ms. was found at Teotihuacán and indicate that the map was in possession of an Indian for years before being sold to Leopoldo Batres. Subsequently acquired by Blake and Edward E. Ayer.

note: Manuscript fragment.|Title devised by cataloger.|Portion of John XVIII.|"The right-hand column of this page survives at Brno in the Czech Republic and a further fragment of the manuscript is at Děčín, also in the Czech Republic. From the evidence of all three fragments it is possible to glean that the original manuscript was a lectionary containing the Old and New Testament lessons to be recited at Mass throughout the church year."--Clemens, R. Introduction to Manuscript studies.|Layout: Written in long lines; ruled in dry point.|Script: Written in Caroline minuscule with pre-Caroline elements. See Clemens, R. Introduction to Manuscript studies for complete description of script.|Origin: Written in south-eastern Germany (possibly Regensburg) in the early 9th century.|Evidence of stitching holes and thread on the top, bottom, and one edge. Additional holes caused by skin defect at top. Fragment was likely used at one time as a part of a binding.|Related shelfmark: Státní oblastní archiv v Brně (Bočkova sbírka) G1, Nr 12.307/5 lat.|Related shelfmark: Státní oblastní archiv v Brně (New Collection) G2, Nr 726 C34

note: Manuscript fragment.|Title devised by cataloger.|Fragment featuring portions of three prefaces to 1 Corinthians removed from perhaps a large Carolingian copy of the Theodulf Bible; text begins "et sitimus et nudi sumus ... habeat et mulier sui corporis ... faceret et qui diu currunt ... "Chicago Newberry Library, Masi Fragm. 14 and the fate of the Theodulf Bible in the long ninth century.|Incorrectly identified in Masi as "Sermon" and in Bischoff as "Excerpta biblica(?)".|Layout: Written in double columns; ruled in dry point; prickings in margin.|Script: Written Caroline minuscule.|Origin: Written in Northern France between 825 and 925 perhaps at the abbey of St. Vaast in Arras or Jumièges Abbey given the inscription locating the fragment at one time in Haspres.|At one time folded horizontally and used as a document wrapper.|Manuscript note on recto in later hand: Déclaration des censes et rentes des fiefs appartenant à 1332[?], Déclaration des censes et rentes des fiefs appartenant Haspres.

physical_description: Extent: 2 leaves : parchment, music ; 287 x 221 (265 x 185) mm
note: Manuscript leaves.|Title from Masi.|Two separate leaves with office hymns from the same manuscript. One leaf starts with vesper hymn for the feast of Mary Magdalene "Votiva cunctis orbita lucis triumphat gr[ati]a qua scandit astra vernula Maria [Christi] fulgida" and ends with the vesper hymn "Gaude visceribus mater in intimis felix" for the feast of the Nativity of Mary; verso includes Michaelmas hymn for lauds "[Christ]e sanctoru[m] decus angeloru[m] rector humani generis [et] auctor nobis [a]eternu[m] tribue benign[us] s[c]andere regnu[m]" and ends with hymn "Exsultet c[a]elum laudibus resultet terra gaudiis apostolorum gloriam sacra canunt sollemnia" from the Common of Apostles. The other leaf startes "ut cum index advenerit Christus in fine seculi, nos sempitetni gaudii faciat esse compores" and continues to the "Eterna Christi munera" and end with "Ihesu corona virginum quem mater illa con- [continuing on verso] cipit quem sola virgo par[turit] hec vota clemens accipe ..." and ends "[Christus] p[ro] nobis mortuus est ... multo magis justificati nunc in sanguine ipsius, salvi erimus ab ira per ipsum".|Used at one time as a part of a binding as paste downs (some text obscured).|Layout: Written in 2 columns of 43 lines.|Script: Written in Caroline minuscule.|Decoration: Rubricated initials.|Origin: Written in Italy or Spain during the 13th century.|Music: Neumes on lower right on one leaf, added in a different hand.|Added text in two different hands including neumes. "A.No. 40. 55 sol communi [?]" writte in a later hand at foot of leaf.|"No. 4" in modern and stamp pasted on same side of one leaf.
